content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I'm loving Starpoint Gemini 2: probably the best space game in year. It's transitioned out of beta nicely, with minimal bugs, and improved optimization. The game has two modes, story and sandbox, and both are quite enjoyable. The control scheme feels a little like Nexus the Jupiter (but not exactly), in the sense that you're the commander of a large ship with various systems (and not just a fighter). Much better than the X series imo.The game excells at allowing you to create the kind of space captain you want to be, and the kind of ship you want to fly. There are three classes, commander, gunner, and engineer, and each excells at different specializations. Commanders are great pilots, and augment their fleets; while, gunners excell at blowing things up; the engineer can create space anomalies like vortexes that suck enemy ships in, deal radiation damage to crews, or they can hack and shut down ship systems.The ships are fantastic. Nearly a hundred different ships of varying classes that you can customize and taylor to your play style. You can control frigates and battleships - and command squadrons of fighters (but there are no fighters you can fly). Place different systems, weapons, and then tweak those systems and weapons with different modules. So, for example, you can tweak your teleporter to improve its capacity, or give it a defensive characteristic, and use it to block enemy teleports. (your ships have troops which can defend against and invade and take over other ships which you can later keep or sell.) Do you install a module with better accuracy, damage, or, for a little more money, both?Finally, there are a variety of things to do. You can be a trader, a smuggler, a pirate (raid and steal ships), or a fleet commander of some sorts. There are anomalies in space that you can simply go out, explore, scan, and document, and gain experience from this. You can ferry VIP or desparately needed supplies between stations. As much variety to the missions as in any space game.My only real complaints, and by no means are these game breaking, is the lack of documentation (there's very little information available on what different game mechanics do, exactly. Which is frustrating, since they obviously took the time to put different mechanics into the game. For example, some guns do "emp" damages, or "radiation" damage, and no where does it say exactly what it means by this, one is just left to assume that radiation hurts crews and emp drains batteries or shields. My second complaint is that there's just too much clutter. Don't get me wrong, the game is beautiful, but everywhere you look there's some beautiful nebulae, star, or simply space debry all around you. Your eyes get overwhelmed by the clutter, never are you allowed to enjoy the simplicity of being amongst the stars. You never get the sense that you're exploring unchartered territory, as there are ships and stations everywhere you go.All in all, excellent game. 8/10.

Every time I resume my game the first thought I have is that this is a great, immersive game. It's really frustrating to see negative reviews because I love this game so much. The developers continue working on it and it keeps getting better which is really saying something since I loved it at early access. recommend for any sci-fi fan that wants a single player open world experience with a ton of ways to play. It's viable to be a miner and buy ships and outfit them just for that. I personally spent several fun hours just doing that, it was great. You can buy and upgrade ships just for smuggle or escort or freelancing. People complain about the expense of ships versus reward of missions; these people simply don't get it. There are lots of ways to build your bank roll and the time and effort it takes make the game more rewarding and immersive. The balance makes it so much better as you progress, you can't just jump from the first ship to the most powerful ship or even the most powerful weapons right away, and that is good. You actually get to enjoy and explore each level of progress , as you get a new ship, or a new upgrade and you slowly work toward that next purchase. All the while playing however you want, avoiding combat in favor of mining and trade which is super fun, figuring out how to avoid destruction or detection while making the kesel run in under 3 parsecs. Or you can be a pirate, good or bad, hijacking ships with a ship optimized just for that sort of activity. So good. So highly recommended.

												This is a really good space game.The game offers various control methods to let you fly your ship like a pilot/dogfighter or play more of a commander role using turret view. At first it takes a while to get used to the controls and fight effectively with a style you like but once you play out a few battles out you will find a control style that suits you and probably end up switching between them depending on the situation and the ship you are using.The graphics and interface are really nice and the game runs very well on my medium system which is an AMD APU with integrated graphics.The sound effects are good but some cool warp like sound effect for the t-drive would be nice. The music is very good although perhaps some more variety would be nice especially for the battle music. The story and voice acting is probably the weakest part of the game but the game offers plenty of freedom to explore space and play how you want to. So you can play like a pirate or a trader, mine or do missions etc. There's plenty to do and it's all fun.The game has a nice rpg element which means you can upgrade your skills for when you are in battle and upgrade perks for various different effects like trading bonuses or ship capture bonuses etc. You can customise your ships weapons and buy bigger and better guns and ships as you progress through the ranks and acquire more credits. Overall I would recommend getting this game, especially if you are into space games.

Posted: May 18, 2015
												I am loving this game - it feels like a mashup of X3, Elite and  a couple of other games.Your starter ship is good mix of everything, good size cargo bay, two weapon points (light - railguns, heavy missiles).  upgrading it is expensive so take care of it.You earn money by trading, completing missions, mining.  You can also try pirating, though this doesn't suit my game play.The universe is a series of hex's that you fly across normally.  Alternatively, their are gateways between locations that require jump drives, worm holes that require increased health (haven't managed to get through one yet) and rift lines, which accelerate your speed whilst you are in the rift.  The subtle difference between worm hole and rift - I think - is that you are exposed to enemy fire in the rift, but not in the wormhole.There is a story (and with the DLC, a second one), but often you will find yourself doing "things".  I targeted a level 2 pirate and thought it would be easy, but he called for help, deciding to avoid the agro, I pushed the engines to max, turned and flew through a rift and ended up in the middle of an uncharted system, alive, but with a battered ship.It is a slow paced game - so far at least - but you have to learn that your ship is NOT a fighter, but a small frigate with a crew and gimballed turrets which you can either fire, or have the crew fire.  Later you can buy carrier vessels or cloaked vessels.  You can also command some sort of fleet (hiring mercenaries to accompany you).Like I say, I am loving this.

												This is a great space combat game, with RPG elements.  Cruising through space, capturing ships, looting and upgrading is a lot of fun.  There are not too many games in this genre. They all seeml to be too old, too complex or they require subscriptions.  Starpoint Gemini 2 is a winner. Short comments on the game:- It is more arcade than simualtion. - The story is not bad, but the presentation is very weak. - At times the voice acting is rediculously bad-  Dont worry about the story becuase the gameplay is engaging and addictive- The graphics are great, minus a few hiccups here and there- Would take about 30-40 hours to play through campaign- Lots to do in this game. DLC is also available and the devs love to support this game- Stop and take a screen capture! F11 will hide all the HUDs so your screen capture comes out like a Carl Sagan wet dream. - The trading and mining is weak, but the value and money making is in capturing enemy ships and selling them and their cargo. Its 5x better than running materials from one side of the map to the other to make money.- There are some great video tutorials on youtube that can jumpstart your ship capturing / pirating skils .  Search: "Tensiaka" on youtube for valuable ship cap[turing and combat tutorials,. They helped me a lot. Make a few million in your first couple hrs ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Despite a few flaws, the gameplay, ship options and open world win out.  I  give it   --   8.5/10

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												This game could be so great. A real worthy successor for the likes of Freelancer and Privateer but it has so many flaws that it is very close to not being recommendable...I still recommend it though for those in urgent need of a space sim who don’t like Elite: Dangerous and can’t wait for Star Citizen since chances are good that you still will get lost in the vicious circle of just one more mission to be one step closer to the next upgrade/weapon/ship.Let’s start with the good things:I really like the music…ok… that’s not all, there is so much to see and do in this game, too. The galaxy is huge and there are many (unique) space stations and planets to visit, missions to do, artifacts/blueprints to track down and especially ships to destroy, buy or capture. Yes, you can capture enemy ships – in theory – that is one part where the design just doesn’t work out so well, more on that later. You also gain experience and level up which will give you skill points and every 5 level a point for perks. Skills feel rather cheap and bad for me. There are 4 active skills (temporary boosts) you can invest your points in, each skill for one of the available weapon systems (railgun, plasma, beam and heavy (missiles)). So you basically decide which is your favorite weapon system and put your skill points into that skill. Perks are passive but also don’t feel that well thought out. Again you can increase the effectiveness of your favorite weapon system up to 3 times and then there are a lot of semi useful perks to invest in. Additionally you get permanent bonuses by getting (steam) achievements (never seen that before in a game...)The actual space simulation needs to get used to, too. I was expecting a feeling like in the old games and even bought a joystick to get the good old times back, but that just doesn’t work out (for me). The shooting is turret based (you have chase cam and no cockpit view anyway), meaning you can see around your ship and you just move the camera freely and aim with your mouse (depending on the turret placement on the ship). Furthermore the hit feedback is so bad that I quickly decided to switch to beam weapons that are instant hit so I know where I aim is what I hit. Railgun and plasma are projectiles flying somewhere in the direction of the enemy and unless you are not fighting a huge freighter close combat you barely see if you hit or not and especially if not why not (ok, it might just need to get used to but beam seems the better solution). Also you can just tell the system to auto fire (that's why there are acurracy stats you can influence, but I want to play the game as space shooter and not strategy game like star wolves so I don't want to use autoaim...)What is really bad and I don’t understand how the design can fail so hard is that you can’t see your enemy information in the hud. Instead the hud is clustered with stupid, bad looking buttons I barely use (which I could easily access by keys). You only see the enemy information when the enemy is in sight and when he is close it is so fast moving that you can barely read it. So what is happening all the time is: There is a bunch of enemies closing in, you see them in the radar, you can target them (via hotkey) but you have either to start flying into their direction (which is a great idea when it turns out that they are deadly) or switch to turret and target mode and move your camera wildly to get them into focus and be able to identify their threat level. Both very inconvenient since you should be able to quickly cycle through all targets and identify them with one glance. Well perhaps I’m missing something, there even is an info hotkey but it won’t work for enemy ships, only for special objects.The other really bad design issue is the character level system. You level up quite fast and the missions you can get (you don’t have to visit stations to get missions, you will get them while in space, which is good) show the suggested level you should have to take that mission. The problem is: the character level does tell♥♥♥♥♥♥about your actual strength. That only depends on your ship and weaponry. So this indicator is useless in the first place. Coincidentally it is also useless in the second place because there are types of missions that are just no brainers – regardless of which level they show. If you have maintenance or science missions you just fly to the target, repair or inspect it aaand… it’s done. On the other hand, good luck with rescue or capture missions, which are often impossible even on low level. So the balancing is very bad in general but luckily you can cheat your way out most of the time: Early game you just start your engine boosters and outrun every enemy, mid game they sometimes start blocking your boost mode but you can have a ship with cloaking device by then and just turn that on. Later this doesn't work and thats when you get in real trouble…Talking about capturing… first you can’t capture 90% of the enemies because they have a larger crew than you have (capturing works this way: grapple the enemy with a tractor beam, send troops via teleporter to his ship, if you have more than him you possibly take over the ship). You can focus on capturing by searching for a cheap ship which allows a large army of troopers on board and you can get perks or officers (you can hire 3 officers for your ship, by the way, you can also hire merc ships that follow you and certain ships allow to take fighters on board you can launch during combat so you end up having your own fleet) that give a bonus on the capturing chances.Second most of the time there are other ships around. So even when you manage to find a capturable ship chances are high that it will get blown apart by some other ship nearby. So it is a great feature in theory that just is no real fun most of the time but satisfying when it finally works.Other weaknesses I like to mention:The presentation is really bad. The main story has a ridiculous voice over most of the time, sometimes just dialog (not sure if it is a bug that voiceover is not playing because the music gets muted anyway) and sometimes just a text popup – atmosphere = 0.The balancing of the main and some side missions is also a bad joke. You will be stuck for hours until you have enough money for a capable ship and after you finally progress you often get much easier missions afterwards.The menus are confusing and tedious to use. E.g. you can either sell all cargo or one good at the merchant, but if you have more than 1 of a good you always have to go to the next screen to select how much of the good you want to sell (well everything!). And you will do that a lot because the screen shows if you are having good, mediocre or bad prices so you most likely don’t want to sell the goods with bad prices and rather fly to the next station. I think the ship loadout menu is simply bugged. edit: it is not bugged, turret handling is just another unintuive feature. Also when I unmount a rocket launcher I lose my missiles. The good thing is that I can store my ships with their loadout in my garage and can swap them easily depending on the situation (cargo space/troop count/gun power).But the weapon/ship prices balancing could be much better. The next better systems are so expensive that it takes hours until you can afford something new that actually feels more powerful. The upgrade flow was much better/faster in Freelancer.Last but not least there are that most annoying situations where a cutscene triggers in the middle of a fight, you can’t do anything but the fight continues in the background usually resulting in your death or at least a great headstart for your enemies.So there are many occasions in the game where I ask myself: Did the developers actually play what they created?And then I go back to the game desperately hunting for the next better ship…

Early Access Review
								DON'T BUY IN CURRENT STATE. i know its early access but its currently unplayable. iv spent 40 minutes "in game" trying to get this to work. upon beginning the free roam, there are 2 missions immidiately available. kill some♥♥♥♥♥♥ and dock at the nearest planet. so, naturally i killed some♥♥♥♥♥♥first and thought id dock after as id likely need to repair my ship or something. upon docking i did all the things needed and tried to leave.... "starpoint gemini 2.exe stopped responding".I have tried everything, even resorting to deleting the game and installing to a different hard drive. no luck. the game is unplayable as docking is an essential part of the game! I'll update this review once another update comes along, but for now its money wasted.---UPDATE---This review was posted shortly after posting on the starpoint gemini 2 forum.I have to say, the devs are absolutely awesome. I posted a post on their forum and within an hour I had a response by both email and on the forum by 2 different devs. I was asked to send them the log and dxdiag report, which i did. By process of elimination they found that the autosave system had corrupted a save file causing the crash i was getting.This is the first time I have had such a great fast response for a problem with a game.10/10 for the devs!--On to the game--It's awesome! I have wanted to play space sims for ages since the first homeworld game, but there just wasn't anything on the market that hit exactly what I wanted. Having read a lot of reviews and watched some on youtube i decided to take the plunge on this... and boy am i glad i did, although i've only played an hour or 2 i can see myself being sucked into this world like i was with homeworld. Graphically it looks beautiful and although i have not played many space games since homeworld i can say its the best iv seen on steam so far.The audio is great! not to intrusive like many games of this kind, but not lacking so much that it gets boring.At present the only option is freeroam which is exactly what I was after. Do what you want, when you want! Although when the campaign is added it will be a great bonus!Mods! its available on the steam workshop! endless possibilities await avid modders! there isnt much on there at  the moment but i can see it blowing up pretty fast!The ONLY thing i have against this game is the tutorial... or lack of one. being completely new to this type of game it would have been a little helpful for it to have some sort of single mission tutorial or something like that. At present it only offers lots of reading.... and if your like me, reading isnt the way you take things in. DOING is the way i find easiest to learn.This is only a minor gripe i have to what i have to say is a superb game. one of my favourites this year so far! :D

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												I purchased this game almost immediately during early access because I had been wanting to play a good space sim for quite a long time. It is a vast improvement over the previous title in the series and successfully creates a fun space sim experience with some rpg progression for your character. Initially after release the game was somewhat buggy, but the developers have ironed out the rough edges and even successfully adapted most of the user interface for gamepad control. Thus far I have spent most of my time in the sandbox mode, but I have recently begun the story playthrough. Both modes are fun to play with the story mode featuring a rather standard, but competently-executed space sim plot. Best of all is that steam workshop is available for the game and there have been many great mods that improve aspects of the gameplay as well as those that create custom content. There is a good diversity of ships and weaponry in the game, with ship types ranging from small gunships and shuttle craft up to battleship size vessels available to be purchased. You can also hire officers who confer stat bonuses and other ships piloted by mercenaries to join you. There are numerous ways to make money including a robust trading economy, asteroids to mine, spatial phenomena to explore, odd jobs to be done, transport/taxi missions, and of course bounty hunter missions.Combat is satisfying, though you certainly feel like more of a ship commander than a pilot. This is probably due to the game's third person perspective which suits the game well because most of the ships you will use are more like capital ships than fighters. To sum it up, this is one of the best single player space sim/rpg's to come out in a very long time. In some ways I enjoy this game more than Elite: Dangerous.

Posted: October 20, 2015
												This game a is a tough one to decide. It really isn't a game that I can sit and dump 8 hours into daily like some of the other games I've played, but it is fun to come back to it every once in a while and get my "freelancer" fix for the week. I personally found this game to be pretty fun when in sandbox/exploration mode. Story mode on the other hand.. was poorly completed, I believe I spent about 20 minutes in, and dumped it due to the appalling voice acting and poorly scripted story.  Now for sandbox I loved flying around blasting and capturing ships to sell at the local stations. I loved upgrading my ship from the inventories of captured  ships. I'm always looking for the shield or weapon improvment. I loved exploring the map and seeing all the cool spacial anomalies. UnfortunateIy, though I did find some general weaknesses in the way content is utilized in the game, there are only a handful of side mission types such as capture ship A, Destroy ship B, or Haul element C these side missions do get old pretty quickly and is a main reason why I cannot dump countless hours into the game in one sitting. Sometimes I also receive missions I have no way in hell of completing, the AI levels way faster than I do... I'll be level 4 with missions that are level 12 around the beginning area. It's ok as you can just drop the mission, but is kinda annoying all the same. Overall, I find the game to be pretty engaging when played casually, but any longer than a couple of hours and I'm ready for something else. I've been looking at Elite: Dangerous but it looks like a tremendous amount of tedious work to play, just from peoples reviews, that and it's much more expensive.To the developer: I really hope you guys haven't given up on this game now that it's considered "Complete" there is still a tremendous amount of possibilities with it, and I would love to see more content(More engaging space stations, etc.) Thanks a ton for creating a game that allows me to get my space sim fix when I feel the urge. Somone you can recognize that you have seen before but make some what elusive so he/she can come back again to hunt you from a jurisdiction you are not welcomed of course, but this should be once in great while not an everytime thing. Another thing is that when you get high level in the game all you see is big hard ships all the time, almost no small ones. In the begining you would see them a lot. content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												There's quite a few things to like in this space trading/shooter game. The developers have managed to infuse a fair bit of live into this one, and it does have some pretty neat game mechanics. The best way of defining it is as a crossover of Freelancer and Starfleet Command, even if I find SPG 2 to be neatly an inferior game to both. Compared with Freelancer, this title hasn't delivered for me the same degree of immersion and engagement with the storyline and the universe that I remember of playing Freelancer. Compared to the second, the tactical combat in this game to be flawed in some departments and shallower, even if there are some cool ideas in here.The stuff I like Even if we're restricted to one single system, there's indeed a lot of places to go and things to see. This is a *big* game. Trading and mining are actually viable professions, not just an side to mercenary or piratical activities. There's lots of ships, and lots of modules to fit your ships with.  Combat is engaging, and fun, at least for some time. I do like very much the "ammo-based" modules (scavenger drones, mining torpedoes, etc.). These modules can be swapped in flight - which might detract from a plausibility point of view, but I personally don't mind it much - and you can actually feel like having a purpose (they're quite useful actually). The game is highly moddable.The stuff that leaves me indifferent or I am not very impressed by While there's a great variety of weapons, I find that rather than having 5 varieties of the same thing with slightly tweaks to range, damage, power drain, etc. it would have made sense to have just one type and increase the "rigging possibilities". Per-module rigging is in  the game, but you can just add one type of rig to one specific module. You can recruit crew, but this crew is reduced to specific buffs to your ship (weapon accuracy, speed, etc.). They level out, and do provide with an extra layer of ship customization. But sometimes the bonuses are so specific that one wonders why are you paying religiously salaries on a monthly basis. There's no enemy leveling - that is, if you go to certain places you may find yourself vastly overmatched by NPC ships. Knowing when to engage and when to fly is an important skill to develop. The problem comes when these "hero" NPCs basically can appear anywhere and the information that allows you to assess whether or not you're outclassed is only visible if you keep it in your sights. Which can be quite difficult. The combat skills system looks good, but very much as with the crew, lacks some depth (and you also wonder why you should bother with those skills).The stuff I plainly don't like The HUD is functional, but I would have really liked that I could have waypoints (that is, locking on locations) and targets (that is, locking on ships and stations) at the same time. Currently, you either have a waypoint or a target. Even worse is that the waypoint/target data is only visible if you have your bow pointed towards the object you locked on. That makes stuff like checking on nearby hostile ships while travelling towards your destination disorienting or just plainly dangerous (since you will close onto these enemies). The world is very much structured like that of Privateer/Freelancer, but crammed into one single star system. What was plausible in those games, here feels a bit uncomfortably contrived. Even if the world is big, I didn't get that "to boldly go where nobody has before" kind of vibe that you get in Elite Dangerous or Evochron Mercenary, for instance. I find the main storyline to be completely uninteresting, and delivered in a very unappealing way.It's a cheap game, indeed, but since I haven't enjoyed it much, I can't really recommend it to anyone.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								I find it hard to say that I recommend this game, or even that I do not.I was a huge fan of Freelancer, and I have spent years looking for something that could fill the hole that Freelancer left behind. While Starpoint Gemini 2 comes close, it's not... quite... there yet. This game is still in development (just recently in beta), so bear that in mind.All of the pieces are there - free roaming, trading, space battles - however, SG2 seems to fall flat a key area - ship movement. The starting vessel, a frigate, I believe, looks like a fish, moves like a fish, but steers like a cow. Most combat is spent circling around trying to get a bead on your enemy for about 1/2 a second before they move out of view once more. By that point, his buddy has been firing lasers up your butt. I'm a space combat noob with this game, but even Freelancer felt like it had more "zip" to ship movement. I had to crank the mouse sensitivity just to feel like there was some kind of response to the controls.Graphically, it's quite nice. Ships, planets, stations and space "stuff" is lovely to look at.The game requires some optimization. When you are in a serious furball with many other ships, I find that the game really chugs and slows down - even if you are not involved in the combat, and it's just nearby.The game is not multiplayer, and I am not clear on whether or not it is ever going to be multiplayer. That is also a major wall for a lot of people. Freelancer was great. Freelancer with friends was amazing.This is not a Freelancer replacement, though it comes close. If you're not concerned about a multiplayer experience, you're not going to find a game that delivers what this one does at this price point. However, I would wait for later in the beta cycle or even for wide release. It's not quite ready for prime time.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												My original review (while the game was still in EA) is shown at the bottom. Please note that the sections on performance are not entirely relevant now, since the game runs much better.REVIEW AFTER RELEASE:---------------------------------------------------------The game is a mix between Freelancer and X3. You can command fleets, hire wingmen, level up skills, buy massive battleships, trade, do missions. It's a lot like Darkstar One too, if we are comparing - but a lot better.The focus here is on large ship battles - and with many ships, rather than smaller dogfigthing. Your starting ship is fairly large ( gunship), and some of the stuff I have seen to buy looks cool. You can climb the ranks and get battleships, dreadnoughts and the like, and command officers and mercs to help you out in battle, either on your own ship or as a wingman. You can even board enemy ships and take control of them, or tractor ships back to stations to sell them.It looks lovely and has a massive open map to explore, complete with anomalies, slipstreams, wormholes, gates, planets, stations asteroid fields, nebula etc. - all you would come to expect from such a game and more.The campaign is basic, but enjoyable. The voice-acting is absolutely atrocious though - the accents are all over the place and it is detrimental in an necessary way. You also have the option to free-roam, doing missions as they come along, trading or becoming a pirate. It has a complete reputation and trading system, allowing you to become anything you want.A lack of multiplayer hits hard, since this game would be infinitely better with it and a real shame it is not included. It also seems to have a fairly repetitive and grindy feel to it - hence the mark of 6/10. If it had multiplayer I think my score would jump to 8/10 instantly though.Jimbo Rating: 6/10REVIEW WHILE IN EA:---------------------------------------------------------It's a mix between Freelancer and X3. You can command fleets, hire wingmen, level up skills, buy massive battleships, trade, do missions. It's a lot like Darkstar One too, if we are comparing - but a lot better.The focus here is on large ship battles - and with many ships, rather than smaller dogfigthing. Your starting ship is fairly large, and some of the stuff I have seen to buy looks cool. You can even board enemy ships and take control of them, or tractor ships back to stations to sell them.It looks lovely, but does seem to suffer from some performance issues. Putting the lengthy loading screens aside, I frequently experienced 0FPS drops when entering new sectors (occurrs quite often), which is a royal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥- especially if it happens to be a wing of enemy fighters.It's still beta, but if they can fix the performance issues (severe slow downs, long load times, crashing) then this game will be a winner.Jimbo Rating: 6/10Note: why have I "not recommended" this game - even though it's good? Simple: it's nigh-on un-playable (or very frustrating) at the moment, what with the aforementioned performance issues.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Starpoint Gemini 2 is easily the best space adventure game available!  Little Green Men Games did a superb job in incorporating those features that make a space exploration game enjoyable while avoiding anything that would be dull.There is a main-story quest line to keep you engaged with multiple side quests to mix things up.  Space travel feels exciting and scenic without taking years in between events (with added wormholes to speed things up a little more).  There are space pirates, some dangerous while others are targets of opportunity for some quick cash, especially if you capture their ship to sell to a nearby friendly space station.There seems to be just the right number of ship and weapon variety to not get overwhelmed while still feeling like you have a choice in weapon loadout and ship type.  There are even some that you acquire through quest lines or obtaining blueprints for exceptional weapon types, including torpedoes, plasma cannons, railguns, etc.Lots of Steam achievements, beautiful scenery, fantastic spacestation design.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Up front:  Not deep enough or fun enough to warrant a $35 entry fee.  Definitely worth it for $10.Pros:+Artwork.  Ships and backdrops are pleasant enough to look at and cruising through space in your ride of choice is nice.+Simple, easy to use interface and controls.  Love the interface.+Straightforward missions+Stable and nicely refined.  Have yet to run in to a "broken quest" or a significant bug of any kind.+Decent enough sized sandbox system to play in.  It takes 15 minutes to fly across Gemini even with the fastest ship. +Game adjusts difficulty rather well as you progress to bigger ships.+Soundtrack is a definite plus that matches the mood of the task at hand.+Lots of factions.  No, they don't really fight all that differently but...they are labeled differently.+Faction loyalty.  It is simple to see who you are friends with and who you should avoid.  System is easy and intuitive.+Decent variety of ships, loots and weapons keeps things interesting.+Fighters and bombers can be launched from you ship.+Perk system.  As you gain rank you can shape your fighting style and abilities.  Easy and effective without being OP.+Steam workshop enabled.  I find looking at the hind end of an Intrepid Class is nicer than the stock ships.Cons:-Game progression can be very grindy at times.-Uncompelling campaign became unbearable because of horrid voice acting.  I began playing free-roam instead.-Ships all fly and feel the same.  A battleship handles just as well as a frigate, it just has more weapons, shields etc. :(-Unable to target specific enemy ship systems.-Sensor range is pitifully low.  You'll always see things before your sensors do.-Combat feels shallow a good portion of the time.  Tactics rarely decide outcome, usually ship stats are it.-Combat AI is downright stupid at times. As a level 18 I destroyed a level 70 pirate because they kept chasing me.  My one pea-shooter gun could hit them from 800 out, their guns could only reach 550.  As they chased me I eventually wore down their forward shield and nearly destroyed them before they turned and ran.  At that point I ran them down, overtook and finished by shooting through their non-existent forward shield.-Controls are simple, but can be awkward at times.  No target padlock option. (Really?)-3rd person views only.  You will never be "in your ship"and that hurts immersion.-No sense of running a crew.  Your "crewmen" are cards with stats that don't progress.-Game does not track ships destroyed, troops lost, total money accrued etc.  Nice touches that are easy to make.-Small variety in mission types.  Scan something, shoot something, ferry something.  That's pretty much it.-No ability to build up a true fleet, can just hire a couple mercs.-No feel of actually influencing events in the game world.-When you dock at a station or planet, all interactions are handled through a simple splash screen.Summary:Starpoint Gemini 2 is a nice little space romp for casual/arcade crowds.  I would personally prefer options available to transform this basic game experience into something a little more hardcore.  Replayability is hurt by lack of simulation options, inability to shape conflict and shallow combat mechanics.  Less than 20 hours in I have a dreadnought class warship, have maxed out alliances with half the factions and explored roughly 60% of the systems in the game.  I do not feel as though I will make any substantial new discoveries at this point, just find combinations of things already previously seen.  The game has begun to feel like a "digital fishbowl" but may come back if I find myself in the mood for mindless point and click with a spaceship involved.  Score: 7.5

												Yes get this game, wait do you need to hear the dialog and be given direction? Okay less one sided. But if those are both no then hell yes get this game.Where to start, I got this game on sale, and wanted to refund it. However I gave it one more try and managed to get through the first little bit, and all of a sudden I loved it like crazy...Side notes I guessI really like the ship details and variety, although I wish there were more. (I always want more ships)The story line got kind of lame and or broken near the end.The main dialog is painful. Punishment for warcrimes painful...So if you are going to give it a go -Turn off the dialog! ----Do IT! (the music is nice though, and in freeroam the dialog is much less death)-And get ready to be spammed like crazy by "helpful" tutorial pop ups as soon as you start. (some are very helpful)----You can skip them or dissable them at your discretion though so not a big deal.-You can zoom out with the numpad +/- keys-You need to restore default keybinds when you start, or the delete key doesn't bring up your tactical view (which once up is handy)I think those are the main things that coloured my lack of enjoyment with it at first, so knowing that you should have a much better run of it. Oh I found the gunner class was less entertaining than the other two classes, even if you are mostly planning on shooting everythingBut seriously I have had a heck of a lot of fun with this game, and will likely continue to do so for a good bit more. I haven't tried all the ships yet and there are still some achievements to go.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Up front:  Not deep enough or fun enough to warrant a $35 entry fee.  Definitely worth it for $10.Pros:+Artwork.  Ships and backdrops are pleasant enough to look at and cruising through space in your ride of choice is nice.+Simple, easy to use interface and controls.  Love the interface.+Straightforward missions+Stable and nicely refined.  Have yet to run in to a "broken quest" or a significant bug of any kind.+Decent enough sized sandbox system to play in.  It takes 15 minutes to fly across Gemini even with the fastest ship. +Game adjusts difficulty rather well as you progress to bigger ships.+Soundtrack is a definite plus that matches the mood of the task at hand.+Lots of factions.  No, they don't really fight all that differently but...they are labeled differently.+Faction loyalty.  It is simple to see who you are friends with and who you should avoid.  System is easy and intuitive.+Decent variety of ships, loots and weapons keeps things interesting.+Fighters and bombers can be launched from you ship.+Perk system.  As you gain rank you can shape your fighting style and abilities.  Easy and effective without being OP.+Steam workshop enabled.  I find looking at the hind end of an Intrepid Class is nicer than the stock ships.Cons:-Game progression can be very grindy at times.-Uncompelling campaign became unbearable because of horrid voice acting.  I began playing free-roam instead.-Ships all fly and feel the same.  A battleship handles just as well as a frigate, it just has more weapons, shields etc. :(-Unable to target specific enemy ship systems.-Sensor range is pitifully low.  You'll always see things before your sensors do.-Combat feels shallow a good portion of the time.  Tactics rarely decide outcome, usually ship stats are it.-Combat AI is downright stupid at times. As a level 18 I destroyed a level 70 pirate because they kept chasing me.  My one pea-shooter gun could hit them from 800 out, their guns could only reach 550.  As they chased me I eventually wore down their forward shield and nearly destroyed them before they turned and ran.  At that point I ran them down, overtook and finished by shooting through their non-existent forward shield.-Controls are simple, but can be awkward at times.  No target padlock option. (Really?)-3rd person views only.  You will never be "in your ship"and that hurts immersion.-No sense of running a crew.  Your "crewmen" are cards with stats that don't progress.-Game does not track ships destroyed, troops lost, total money accrued etc.  Nice touches that are easy to make.-Small variety in mission types.  Scan something, shoot something, ferry something.  That's pretty much it.-No ability to build up a true fleet, can just hire a couple mercs.-No feel of actually influencing events in the game world.-When you dock at a station or planet, all interactions are handled through a simple splash screen.Summary:Starpoint Gemini 2 is a nice little space romp for casual/arcade crowds.  I would personally prefer options available to transform this basic game experience into something a little more hardcore.  Replayability is hurt by lack of simulation options, inability to shape conflict and shallow combat mechanics.  Less than 20 hours in I have a dreadnought class warship, have maxed out alliances with half the factions and explored roughly 60% of the systems in the game.  I do not feel as though I will make any substantial new discoveries at this point, just find combinations of things already previously seen.  The game has begun to feel like a "digital fishbowl" but may come back if I find myself in the mood for mindless point and click with a spaceship involved.  Score: 7.5

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I love this game!! Though it should come with a warning: "Warning, this game will make you lose sleep!" heh. I've played quite a few space games throughout the years, X3 series, Wing Commander, Freespace 2, Starlancer, EVE, Star Wars X-Wing and more and this one ranks right up there imo. If you're into these types of games I highly recommend checking this one out! Pros:-Great graphics-Epic music-Fun sandboxy type of do whatever you want freedom-Devs are very active and responsive (big seller for me)-Ease of modding (probably my favorite aspect of this game)Cons:-Requires a bit of tweaking to optimize and run smoothly on lower end systems. (Though there are mods that help, and the community is always willing to help with this)-No Multiplayer (but this isn't a factor for me, in fact, it's one of the reasons I bought this game...no griefers, no obsessively overpowerful others pwning you within the first ten seconds of you logging in. And it doesn't take 8 months to be able to fly a battleship! :) )I can't think of too many cons because the devs are always working on improving things, and fixing the few bugs that have surfaced here and there. Every time I think of a con, I find out they've already fixed it!Also, I have never actually published a mod before this game. It is insanely easy to mod...you want to change your loading screen? Easy. Want to change the music? Sure, you don't have to go through some maddening process of decrypting game files just to get to them, and then re-encrypt them using 20 different programs just to do that. Want to fly a ship that looks like a banana? Yep. And you don't have to learn eleventy different programming languages to do that. There are fantastic guides that help as well. And the devs are always around somewhere willing to help. Yea, big plus for me.The sandboxy aspect is a big plus too. Want to just roam around for a bit and blow stuff up? Sure. Want to just mine and get rich trading? Yep. Want to be a wanted criminal with a limited life expectancy? No worries.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												This is (in my opinion) one of the greater games on Steam. For those who are looking for a TASTE of EVE here you go. This game is almost like a baby stepping stone into the EVE universe. While the game does have its flaws as I will state, I believe that this sandbox game has great potental. Now, I will say that I do not believe it is worth $40 just yet. The modding community has yet to take off and you can cheat the game by simply opening your save in Notepad++ and editing the data. Which I believe somewhat cuts the fun out of comparing achievements to other players globally. The missions of hunting the heros are somewhat wonky as well because it seems they jump systems if you watch the map. Just as well, there is a very large difficulty spike in the game that you must prepare for. As you reach a certain level your enemies gain vet rank and you probably have yet to make enough money to even afford a ship that can stand up to them. (Unless you did what I do and stole a ship from the pirates) Now for the positives. This game has BEAUTIFUL scenery. For an indie game, a lot of time was put into this game and its atmosphere. The story and voice acting are a bit stale, but the fact that they are there is awesome. And the story, while being a bit dry, actually does make some form of sense. So kudos! At the start of the game you may pick to be a captain, engineer or another class that excels in firing. You may hire mercenaries to board ships or even follow you in to battle which is what the captains perks stand for. The shooter class perks somwhat speaks for itself. But I played as an engineer as the perks seemed to outweigh the others. The story is the same regardless of your class, but each class has its own specialties with 4 main "moves" But those moves have 5 evolutions within each allowing you to alter them as you go to tailor your playstyle up to the max level of 80. There are a plethora of planets to explore as well as tons of ships to purchase and try out. All in all, if you enjoy sandbox style games and as well as enjoy the beauty of flight or space travel, I recommend this game. I also recommend trying it if your thinking about EVE online. This game is a MUCH simpler thing. But it has many of the same aspects as well as can help you decide if you would even enjoy the simple aspects of what EVE offers before you worry about the more complex matters.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												So far really enjoying this game. I am a huge fan of open-universe space games with ship and fleet customisations, but I do not like MMO-games (so unfortunately EVE is out of the picture for me). This game, to me, fills an X shaped void. It really offers a lot of what X3 had, and with some new and fresh ideas because it isn't X! And where the original Starpoint Gemini I couldn't get into because it simply wasn't as good as X, SG2 genuinly is. It is also particularly well timed, I loved all of the previous X games, until they released X reunion, which is probably the most sad, dissapointing and pathetic game ever made and totally missed the point of X and why it was good. I am glad to see that the developers of Starpoint Gemini have worked on, enhanced and listened to what space-gamers really want, and developed something that really fits. I am excitedly looking forward to where they take SG games in the future. I know I am basically saying "it is the new X", believe me when I say that coming from me, that is huge praise. If I were to nit pick, I would say that SG2s UI could use a little tweaking, the ability to zoom out on the map and a tool for selecting your own ships on the map and I'd like to see some of the fleet controls from X3 (for example telling a ships computer to go somewhere, protect something or trade something). I would also like to see space station ownership, and more skills and mods aimed at ship capture. But these are not huge criticisms, just where I think SG could be improved.

												Starpint Gemini 2 is the definite successor of Wing Commander: Privateer and Freelancer.  I have been waiting for many years for a team to go back to the simple roots of many upgradeable ships and challenging freelance type missions and this game DELIVERS BOTH!  The learning curve is relatively easy and the incorporation of using the mouse and keypad versus a joystick has been accomplished (IMO) flawlessly.  I am enthralled by the fact that regardless of how much I upgrade my ship (currently running a Cruiser and looking to upgrade to a Dreadnaught) that the missions are still challenging.This is not a game of incredible voice acting or a fantastic storyline but the visuals and extremely sound mechanics make the game a pleasure to play.  My favortie addition is the boarding feature!  Wait until you have a ship with 90 or so troops and you can take Frigates with 30 - 50 tropps with ease and make a big payday when you tow your capture into port.  (NOTE:  Click on the GREEN flag in the troop transport window, after it turns from gray to green, to send more troops.  This is not spelled out in the manual.)Congrats to theis set of independent game creators!  Great job!

Posted: April 12, 2016
												I wrote this review in January of 2015 on Metacritic.  I thought I posted it to Steam, but did not.  This game deserves a review.  Here's a copy/paste of my former review.  The game has only gotten better through expansions.I am a Star Citizen backer. Want to know a dirty little secret? I love and crave 3rd person space games. En route to searching for something to fill this desire, I came across this game. "A Steam sale?" I asked. "Twenty-four bucks?" I blinked. "I spend that on 2-3 drinks at a restaurant with the wife..." So, I plucked this one out of the Steam shelf, downloaded and started playing. Eight hours later I looked up and saw it was 4am. "Woah..." The next (read: later that) day I dove into the Starpoint Gemini 2 Community and learned I was late to a really cool party. Did you love Freelancer? Are you craving a 3rd person Space game? What are you waiting for...? Pick this gem up ASAP. There are few games that are so worth your money that you'll want to encourage others to purchase, but this is certainly one for me. In a day when space sims are seeing a great resurgence, it's refreshing to see a game that's not afraid to be 3rd person and give the player a bit of a relaxed take on space. I feel like a Malcom Reynolds, flying around in my ship, always with my eye on a new shiny, but lovingly holding onto, in my case, "Big Red," until the time is truly right. There's dangers around every planet, but I've got a crew, a purpose, seemingly endless space to explore (certainly more than my limited time allows), and a ship. There's even a fun plot-line to follow along as you make your way in the galaxy--or don't; whatever--it's all up to you. I can assure you that if you want a rewarding, relaxing, and immersive (but not taking itself too seriously) space game, this is it. I give it a 9 (I'd have done 9.5 if it let me) because of the somewhat outdated UI, and the graphics are not the most polished. That said, the graphics do not detract from the game too much and again, it's sort of a breath of fresh air of late with the Elite: Dangerous's and Star Citizen's of the world. The development team has their ear to the forums and though I am new to the scene, they appear to be largely shaping the game around their community. It's mod friendly, and seemingly more so as time goes on, and there's already some great mods out there. It's much of anything you want in a fun game. Cheers.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Star Point Gemin 2 is a fantasic starship space genre game that will have you playing for hours on end. I’ve spent more than 60 hours with the game at this point and I’ve only just scratched the surface. I’ve primarily been playing in the games “free roam” mode as that was the real draw of the game for me. I knew from the outset that I wanted a game that gave me the ability to explore, fight, mine and trade at my own leisure and do so in my own ship like a “real” space captain. After researching SP♥♥♥♥ bit I realized that this would be the game that would allow me to do all of that.I’m not a diehard space sim player so games like EVE Online and Star Trek Online have always kind of intimidated me. I’ve never really had an interest in the X3 series (my loss probably) but I have played Sins of a Solar Empire and the Homeworld series. It's been a while since I've played anything space related but lately I’ve become re-interested in the genre with games like Star Citizen and Elite: Dangerous on the horizon. I knew I wanted to play a game that felt huge and expansive but I didn’t want to play a game that made me feel like a small fish in a huge pond. I’m a casual player so the size and scope of this game feels just right to me. The game's setting is huge and there is a lot to do in it. Also, it seems like the devs are really committed to making the game better all the time which made the choice to buy it all the more easy to make. The fact that I’ve continued to play it so much is a testament to how good it actually is.SPG2 reminds me specifically of two games I’ve played before, Nexus: The Jupiter Incident and Star Trek: Starfleet Command. Although I’ve played many other space genre games since, I really wanted to play something that felt similar to those two games. SPG2 has a surprising amount in common with Starfleet Command which also allowed you to “tractor beam” aka grapple ships, scan anomalies and commandeer other spacecraft with “marines” aka troopers. I haven’t played that game in over 15 years but I remember how much fun it was to do those things in the game.These are some of the things I like about SPG2:-	the music is great especially the main theme-	the ship designs are cool and I know there are still tons more to discover-	the space station designs are great and varied which is a plus-	the variety of weapons and their FX in game look great-       the descriptions for items and npcs in the game are numerous and often amusing-       there are many mods availiable which help to enhance gamplayThe randomness of missions and enemies is great but whether or not you like this aspect of the game will depend on how much you like doing things in this universe. After awhile the missions can seem repetitive but luckily the fact that the level required to do each mission changes all the time, forces you to decide which missions to do or not to do. This in turn helps mix things up a bit and keep things interesting.The only issues I have with the game so far are the way the menus in stations and on planets were a bit confusing at first and still seem a bit cumbersome to navigate. Also I wish there was a bit more 'humanity' in the game. By that I just mean it would be cool if officers had portraits in addition to their names and when ships attacked you they too had portraits instead of just insignias. I know that's a huge 'ask' as there are already a huge amount of randomized officer names in the game. Perhaps a feature that allowed you upload your own portraits to the game (specifically for officers) could be cool. Also, I’m not entirely sure, but I think officers gain experience the longer they are on your ship. I hope so but it would also be cool if they could steadily gain loyalty for additional bonuses.Other than that I’ve really enjoyed this game and am glad I bought it.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												I'm going to give this a 5/10 at the moment.  The content that is present is well done and relatively stable/bug free.  Ship combat is fun for a while, and space is visually interesting with a few suprises.  But get a few hours in and the game starts to feel kind of pointless.  There is a faction system, but it doesn't do much of anything.  There is trading and mining, but neither give money at anywhere near the rate fighting does.  There are generated "missions", but they are extremely easy and give very little in the way of rewards (you'll probably do them just to have something to do).  There are enemy bases and structures, but you can't destroy them (you can get them to one health and they just hang there, and frankly it isn't hard at all to do that).  You end up collecting money to buy a bigger ship to collect more money to buy an even bigger ship (which isn't very rewarding, as the ship models are so small in relation to one another you dont get the sense that you have a bigger ship)...The game isn't garbage, and the devs are very nice and responsive.  At $5-$10 give it a shot, but not at $40.  The caveat here is there is a very soid framework to make a much better game (really this game is in the bin with so many others that are really in early-mid beta, but release early to make money).  If there is a content update that adds player bases and the ability to capture territory, balances out mining and trading, and puts in other end-game content and empire building mechanics, this game will be a 9/10 easy.  It feels like these things were intended, but just haven't made it in.  So, if you see a big update after this review, maybe give it a try.  Otherwise, skip it until there is a big steam sale (or skip entirely, if a space grind isn't your thing).

I definitely recommend!

Back to the game, It is not too complex, don't get me wrong, I love complexity, but Starpoint Gemini does require quick thinking and reaction; observing it evolve through updates / patches since I bought it in the spring of 2014, the developers seem pretty intent on making this game something to speak of and they are certainly not ditching their creation, unlike other devs I've seen veer away from working on a game, not keeping to their promises.I recommend this game, for sure, especiallyl at this sale price, $10.49 as of September 28, 2015. content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												This games is awesome, hands down. You pilot a ship, it starts out a bit small but you can get very large ones. The thing that makes this game awesome is that you can just go anywhere and do anything. There is a story mode but it's not really important or vital to follow, I have mostly ignored it so far. Combat is a lot of fun, there is no "strategic pausing" or anything to strategize, and you really have a ton of stuff to micromanage. That said, your mechanical ability to think quickly, pilot your ship, use items/abilities, and position properly have HUGE outcomes on the combat. If you're good, you can do a lot with a little ship, if you're bad you can to little with a big ship. Combat is definitely an extremely fun aspect in this game but there is also so much more than just fighting other ships. The exploration in this game is really amazing. The landmarks (stations, planets, asteroid field locations etc) are static, everything else, the quests, the enemies, etc are completely random. You can pick a direction, put all power to engines, and fly to your hearts content. I actually spent an hour flying completely off the map. There isn't really anything noticeable out there except for a few enemies and such but it  definitely took me an hour to fly back. So yea, the exploration aspect in this game is huge, think skyrim in space but no drauger. So yea, awesome space battles, great exploration in a beautiful backdrop, it's really a lot of fun. The icing on the cake is the soundtrack. It's just ambient electronic but man it sets the mood well. I swear, this is the most relaxing game to play. Just mine asteroids, listen to the music, and be wisked away to a whole other solar system.Anyway, if you like exploring, enjoy space, and like relaxing for hours on end running cargo, hunting pirates, and looking at stars, you'll like this game.

												This gem is somewhere between the X series (vertical learning curve) and Galaxy on Fire 2 (my dog plays this game) in terms of difficulty with some of the best combat in any space game I've ever played.  SPG2 may not have any entirely new concepts or features but it has taken a lot from past games and the end product does all the little things right.  Ultimately this game meets the same fate as Skyrim, a giant world that is unfortunately only about 5 feet deep.  While I have absolutely no regrets throwing out $28 for it, I can't help but feel this game will be so much better in a year thanks to workshop support and a dev team that truly cares about their B - level game.  While the voice acting is pretty bad, It isn't House of the Dead 2 bad so it's playable, other than the voices the sound is pretty good, I could wish for a few more effects and songs but that's just nitpicking.  The one thing I truly don't like about this game is the faction system, if you do assignments in the Trinity sector your reputation goes towards lawful...Which means all lawful factions like you more, the unlwaful (pirates) well, they never liked you anyway.  If I do things in the Trinity sectors I want perks in the Trinity sectors, not halfway across the solar system.Unlike most titles I am actively looking forward to DLC for this game, which I'm hoping will greatly increase depth.-Throw in some: player built space stations, automating a freight company that I have built/stolen and funded, faction control, and territory conquering and this could truly be something special.8.5/10

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Where to start... The game itself requires some minor polish, mainly in the balancing sector, but it's already at a very good/stable state otherwise. There are various tasks to do inside the game, such as exploration, boarding ships, mining, trading(These do still need balancing.) and ofcourse, the campaign mode and pewpew fighting. The game is fairly complex, once you start getting into it, learning to fly and maneuver different ship classes, the firing arcs of various ships, finding fighting tactics that work for you and your ship, the enhancement system... And for those who get bored quickly after having played through the storyline, which did happen to a lot of players in other games such as Freelancer, you do have a nice amount of achievements to hunt, some of which aren't exactly easy to accomplish. Nothing is stopping you from hunting down the "Heros" either. ;)The community and the devs are active and communicating a lot, which reflects into the product and the pace patches, fixes and balancing attempts are coming through. There are plans for an expansion and DLC, which will further add to the amount of content in the game and ofcourse, the community made mods, which will be the crowning jewel of this game. The tools might not be fully functional yet, but as soon as the game itself is at a state where the devs and community are happy, the tools will be recieving some much needed love.A lot has been said about the game in many of the reviews, but here's another list of just some of the features already in the game and some which are being worked on:Already in:-Boarding Ships.-Working Campaign.-Lots and lots of ships.-Weapon/ship system enhancement.-Trading.-Dynamic events which effect item prices.-A large amount of space to explore, which can also be further expanded.-Lots of different factions.(Which will also get some more love in the future.)-Freeroam mode for those who don't wish to play the campaign.-Mercenaries to act as your backup.-Blueprints.-Working collision system.-Cloaking!-Heroes to hunt,-Mods.Planned/in the works:-Player owned faction and base(s).-Dynamic struggles for power/regional control between factions. Once this is implemented, every single playthrough will be and feel different!-Expansion/DLC.-Modding Tools.(Currently some work, some don't. Somewhat prone to crashes.)-Improvements to the HUD and other elements of the UI.-An entirely new ship class.(Larger, naturally. Bigger is always better!)... and the list goes on.If you aren't a fan of space sims or dislike games with emphasis on exploration, this might not be for you, as there is no MP in the game to increase its lifespan. However, if you do like what you've seen/read and can get past the fact that there is no MP and that the game relies entirely on mods/expansions/DLC to keep breathing fresh life into it, then this game just might be a perfect fit for you. Atleast I've completely fallen in love with the game.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Star Point Gemin 2 is a fantasic starship space genre game that will have you playing for hours on end. I’ve spent more than 60 hours with the game at this point and I’ve only just scratched the surface. I’ve primarily been playing in the games “free roam” mode as that was the real draw of the game for me. I knew from the outset that I wanted a game that gave me the ability to explore, fight, mine and trade at my own leisure and do so in my own ship like a “real” space captain. After researching SP♥♥♥♥ bit I realized that this would be the game that would allow me to do all of that.I’m not a diehard space sim player so games like EVE Online and Star Trek Online have always kind of intimidated me. I’ve never really had an interest in the X3 series (my loss probably) but I have played Sins of a Solar Empire and the Homeworld series. It's been a while since I've played anything space related but lately I’ve become re-interested in the genre with games like Star Citizen and Elite: Dangerous on the horizon. I knew I wanted to play a game that felt huge and expansive but I didn’t want to play a game that made me feel like a small fish in a huge pond. I’m a casual player so the size and scope of this game feels just right to me. The game's setting is huge and there is a lot to do in it. Also, it seems like the devs are really committed to making the game better all the time which made the choice to buy it all the more easy to make. The fact that I’ve continued to play it so much is a testament to how good it actually is.SPG2 reminds me specifically of two games I’ve played before, Nexus: The Jupiter Incident and Star Trek: Starfleet Command. Although I’ve played many other space genre games since, I really wanted to play something that felt similar to those two games. SPG2 has a surprising amount in common with Starfleet Command which also allowed you to “tractor beam” aka grapple ships, scan anomalies and commandeer other spacecraft with “marines” aka troopers. I haven’t played that game in over 15 years but I remember how much fun it was to do those things in the game.These are some of the things I like about SPG2:-	the music is great especially the main theme-	the ship designs are cool and I know there are still tons more to discover-	the space station designs are great and varied which is a plus-	the variety of weapons and their FX in game look great-       the descriptions for items and npcs in the game are numerous and often amusing-       there are many mods availiable which help to enhance gamplayThe randomness of missions and enemies is great but whether or not you like this aspect of the game will depend on how much you like doing things in this universe. After awhile the missions can seem repetitive but luckily the fact that the level required to do each mission changes all the time, forces you to decide which missions to do or not to do. This in turn helps mix things up a bit and keep things interesting.The only issues I have with the game so far are the way the menus in stations and on planets were a bit confusing at first and still seem a bit cumbersome to navigate. Also I wish there was a bit more 'humanity' in the game. By that I just mean it would be cool if officers had portraits in addition to their names and when ships attacked you they too had portraits instead of just insignias. I know that's a huge 'ask' as there are already a huge amount of randomized officer names in the game. Perhaps a feature that allowed you upload your own portraits to the game (specifically for officers) could be cool. Also, I’m not entirely sure, but I think officers gain experience the longer they are on your ship. I hope so but it would also be cool if they could steadily gain loyalty for additional bonuses.Other than that I’ve really enjoyed this game and am glad I bought it.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												I'm going to give this a 5/10 at the moment.  The content that is present is well done and relatively stable/bug free.  Ship combat is fun for a while, and space is visually interesting with a few suprises.  But get a few hours in and the game starts to feel kind of pointless.  There is a faction system, but it doesn't do much of anything.  There is trading and mining, but neither give money at anywhere near the rate fighting does.  There are generated "missions", but they are extremely easy and give very little in the way of rewards (you'll probably do them just to have something to do).  There are enemy bases and structures, but you can't destroy them (you can get them to one health and they just hang there, and frankly it isn't hard at all to do that).  You end up collecting money to buy a bigger ship to collect more money to buy an even bigger ship (which isn't very rewarding, as the ship models are so small in relation to one another you dont get the sense that you have a bigger ship)...The game isn't garbage, and the devs are very nice and responsive.  At $5-$10 give it a shot, but not at $40.  The caveat here is there is a very soid framework to make a much better game (really this game is in the bin with so many others that are really in early-mid beta, but release early to make money).  If there is a content update that adds player bases and the ability to capture territory, balances out mining and trading, and puts in other end-game content and empire building mechanics, this game will be a 9/10 easy.  It feels like these things were intended, but just haven't made it in.  So, if you see a big update after this review, maybe give it a try.  Otherwise, skip it until there is a big steam sale (or skip entirely, if a space grind isn't your thing).

												8/10 Free Roam Space Sandbox. Limited to one ship at a time, like Elite or Freelancer, but the options are very wide. Uncloak and Pirate hapless enemies, Haul freight, Mine, Smuggle, command a Battleship with it's own fighters like Galactica, explore space with an independent powerful Cruiser with beams & torpedo loadout- it's all possible. Limited customizing possible on the visuals, but you can spend time tinkering with engines, cloaks, weapons loadouts, transporters etc till you get her exactly how you like.  Random missions in Freeroam mode give you a foothold on things to do, but they are entirely optional. You can switch sides, and support any faction you like.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I want to enjoy this game.  I can honestly see all the potential it has.  But I I have to hesitate in giving it a full thumbs up, but it's also not a full thumbs down.  As this is being written during Early Access, I can forgive any shortcomings.  Like I said, I can see the potential.  But try as I might, I'm just not feeling it.To start, I've always loved these types of games and felt they never made enough.  A space sim seems to have unlimited potential, but I prefer to avoid things that require subscriptions and groups like MMOs.  Conversely, I recall fond memories of doing just that in Earth and Beyond, lo so many years ago.  But what I loved most about Earth and Beyond is I recall enjoying crafting my ship and making it mine.  I'd say the same for the Lightspeed add-on to Star Wars Galaxies.  Clunky though it was, I thoroughly enjoyed taking those ship parts I blasted out of enemy ships and hoarding them, finally upgrading when I would get the time and adding it to my ship.  I felt like I owned that more.  Though you can certainly buy different ship parts here, there aren't that many right now, and some of the differences aren't readily apparent.  I can't even easily compare the old with the new.Funny enough, I started drawing comparisons to, of all things, the game FTL.  Though you don't actively fly a single thing, and the game basically consists of just a handful of screens, it does give you the ability to upgrade your ship in a way that makes you feel like you're in control of it.  And while even the upgrades themselves are a simple thing, I never really find myself using the same configuration over and over again because I find random things and random times.  Here, I feel less like I'm thinking on my feet and thinking more about where I'm flying next (fun, yes, but limited).Similarly, again, Early Access-itis: you get plopped into the game and are told nothing.  Zippo.  Sure, the tutorial is there, but it's not interactive.  It tells you what to do on one screen, then you need to close it out to try it, and  then reactivate the tutorial screen to move on.  Very clunky.  On the plus side, the controls feel pretty good and are easily customized, and yet, for it being space, it feels rather tight.  Granted, it's a game, so not everyone wants to sit there and patiently watch the seconds tick away, but it almost feels too quick.  It is space, after all.  If only to hammer the point home, once I figured out how to get where I was going, it didn't seem like I had to do much once I got there.  I also wonder about the items you get.  They don't seem to have much more purpose than to provide you with money.  And while that's all good, it also seems very limited.  Okay, I've got a cargo hold full of all these different things...that don't have anything special about them other than how much money they fetch you.  Then what?  Wash, rinse, repeat?  I could see where  the full game, story and all, would provide more substance, but I would hope it's substantial, because right now, like I said, I don't feel "at home" in this game.  I don't feel like I have a reason to be out flying, that my ship is no different than any other NPC ship flying around, randomly doing things "just because."So, like I said to start, I can see the potential: it looks amazing, the controls are customizable and feel natural, and there appears to be a real desire to embrace the mysteries of space.  Unfortunately, things feel like they move real fast, that customization needs to be greatly expanded to get some real tinkering done on ship, and that I'm not just moving from A to B to A again.That said, I eagerly await more content and gladly support the game.
