content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Alright. First of all, I am not going to comment on the technical issues currently existing in the game. It's very resource hungry, and there's an unpatched memory leak forcing you to close the game roughly every hour. The devs will have to address this before the final version is released. Also: What this game IS NOT, is "Eve Offline". Anyone who says such things is severely overhyping the title. It is, at best, a Freelancer clone.Now for the meat of the review.=THE GOOD=1. Fluid interesting combat, but don't expect dogfights. It plays more like traditional naval battles with turrets and missiles.2. Responsive dev team. They take community input to heart and make changes as needed.3. Very large map. So large, that travelling from one corner to the other would take you probably 20-30 minutes.4. Seamless travel. There's still warpgates and jumpdrives available to the player, but no "zones" or loading screens.5. Many different factions enables you to work with and shoot whoever you want.6. Many different ships. Enough variety to keep it fresh and interesting. 7. A bounty system that enables you to live out your inner Boba Fett. Be the space cop you always dreamed of being!=THE BAD=1. Ship designs are... different. Maybe I'm used to the look of EVE, or WingCommander, or Homeworld, but I expect space ships to have a certain bulkiness and weight to them. Most of the ships in this game either look like some derivative of a shark/fish, or an insect. It's very strange cruising along and seeing a flying praying mantis scoot by. The rest look dated. It's like the devs took the Freelancer inspiration a little too far, and saddening that the mod community is starting to produce models far better than the "official" ones shipping with release. You can have more than 5,000 polys on a model these days, guys...2. Combat. I know I said it was a "good" aspect, but I just want to make something clear here. 90% of battles I've been in, no matter what ship I'm using, no matter what my loadout is, I can win by pushing three buttons on my keyboard: Railgun skill -> Damage amp -> Fire at will. Done. And this is playing on Hard Mode. There is something inherently wrong with being able to destroy a dreadnought with a frigate.3. Combat (again). Missiles and other 'heavy weapons' are very pointless. It's odd you can only fire them once the little orange bar on your reticle fills up, nearly defeating the point of having them. On one ship, the Oppenheimer, I opted for no missiles or heavy weapons of any kind and noticed absolutely no difference in my ability to destroy anything and everything. They're effectively redundant, and with the current system in place I cannot see this ever changing.4. Ship customization is basically not a thing. People have been praising customization in their reviews, but I feel they are being dishonest. You can customize your ships in-so-far as being able to change their paint job or logo, or how shiny it is. That's it. As far as gear and parts are concerned, you're only tuning stuff already on your ship, and you do so by scrolling down a list and simply getting the most expensive thing on there. You're not really buying new engines, or an expanded cargo hold, or a different powerplant. You're not weighing the options and going "Hmm! If I get this, then I can't have that!" It's not at all a mod system like what's in EVE. If your ship doesn't have a cloak, you'll never have a cloak. If your ship has crappy shields, you'll always have crappy shields. Etc. I hope this changes before release, but I somehow doubt it.5. There's no reason to go beyond a cruiser. I can kill or capture anything with a Saratoga. I basically stopped playing when I towed a dreadnought into port and cashed it in. Apparently 90 guys can overpower a ship staffed by thousands.6. It's far too easy to hit 'end game'. The first few hours of playing was just me saving up to buy a frigate. From my frigate, I captured a destroyer. From my destroyer, I captured enough ships to get a cruiser. From my cruiser, I was unstoppable. I did this very rapidly, despite pouring tens of hours into simple exploration. 7. Bugs. Yeah yeah, it's beta. I know. But it is rather silly flying up to a bounty, seeing they're "blue" (allied), and then just following them around until someone kills them, yet -I- get rewarded with the bounty. I wish that worked in real life where if I watch the cops bust someone, cash magically appears in my pocket.8. No main quest. It's supposed to have one eventually, but despite being beta none of it is playable. You're stuck doing random low-paying generated missions, or inventing your own fun. The the latter can be quite enjoyable, but you will run out of stuff to do in a hurry. =Final Thoughts=Despite its issues, Starpoint Gemini 2 is quite the fun little sandbox and probably the closest thing we're ever going to get to a successor to Freelancer. Freelancer was far more polished as an overall product, however, and until SG2 introduces a TRUE parts and customization system (which I consider to be a much greater problem than combat, or even optimization woes), it will not hold a candle to Eve Online. This is a beta that plays like an alpha, but if you're hungry for a spaceship game with solid promise, then this is it.6/10.

								Wow, suprised! This game was actually dang good! The reviews werent wrong at all. Its very similar to the X3 / X series of games except without the headaches, no laggy menus, no shoddy UI/maps, basically its everything that you wanted X:rebirth to be.. almostIts not the best game in the world, however the developers are hard at work polishing this title into a true gem. Theres a few small issues and bugs left to be fixed and some features that will be implemented in the future, so this title has a bright future ahead of it, even though its worth buying As-is.  Theres moddability in the game itself so im sure the modding community will be able to fix/implement what the devs do not. The devs are actually active on the forums and not just to censor creativity and announce p2w and microtransaction garbage. If you like RPGs, buy it, support it, who knows? This platform/title could have a VERY bright future ahead of it.  This is probably the only Early Access title that isnt a rip off out of the lot.... And that's coming from one of the most virilent critics of the early-access system, so you know its for real.

There are three character classes, different type of ship classes, different kinds of ships within the classes, four different weapon types and tons of missions to do in sandbox mode.  I've been playing as the gunner,  especializing on weapons systems,with the ability to adds different bonuses to the weapon system of choice. My weapon of choice being rail-guns.  It's up to you how you want to play. You have the option of playing as a pirate, enforcer, bounty hunter, miner, trader or a freelancer (combination of all). How effective you are doing each type of job depends on the ship, the combination of skills you select as you increase in experience and buying a license. License determine how much money you will receive depending on what the license is for. For example, a mining license will get you more money when selling ore, a police license will reward you with moneyfor everykill, and so on so forth. The point of it all is to make money, so you can get better ships and better gear, you know, the same old formula that keeps us coming back for more.  Overall I really like this game and if you are a fan of freelancer and games likes these I dont think you will be disappointed. The best part? It's only  going to get better.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This, game. I am enjoying it for all the reasons I bought it. Specifically, the play a game with the full freedom to drift aimlessly in space to look at something and say to myself... "I should go there" and be able to go there.  Issues arise in that so far there is no campaign, so there is a no guided leveling structure. Which is nice and freeform, but leaves you with a... "hrmm, now what", feeling similar to the sims or minecraft if you don't have a personal goal.  So far, you start off as  a rather beefy frigate off the bat, and from there are told there are other things you can do with your life beyond be a pirate/merc. Don't listen to that voice, stealing ships via boarding parties is the only way of acquiring money relatively quickly beyond the rare, bounty list job.  Which brings up space combat! This is both so much fun, and so much rage. Fun part! Depending on your choice of weapons, you are able to join random battles in space with next to no reprecursions as the two parties fight for life and you zap your enemy (see red guy), due to some laughably long range and guess shooting. Or you are able to watch in horror as you enter an area of space where everyone has some horrifyingly powerful guns that destroy your shields, hull, and happiness before you can make a pass at escape. Major issue is that you don't know what they are packing in weapons, you can't tell untill they open up on you, and the little info blerp provided is vague, very much so. The description varies from "trivial" to "Impossible", but you are not informed how they are rated to determine threat level to you. I seem to think it is an unspoken amalgamation of your ships type, and load out mixed with your level. But!  Trivial enemies in twos can wreck your life for reasons you are unsure of (maybe they are small glass cannons that are only GUN). Deadly enemies can just float around you in vain trying to bring their weapons to bare before dying to the explosion of their metal death trap.  Also, each ship has a load out of weapons, that are placed on four compass based directions on your ship, and each has a firing arc that is not discussed much, and even some of the fully decked vessels will always have blind spots in their firing patern.  So you are shooting, zapping, and hitting with all due fun then slightly tilt your ship to the left and stop. The weapons also have a range... which is an ignorable text box since it only matters in "Fire at Will" mode, unless you are being shot at then your AI ignore it just like you do and open up shooting everything like a Ork Freeboota.Exploration is fun, though potentially deadly since the whole area is teeming with bandits looking for the sweet rolls in your ships captain's quarters. There are about four mains ways of travel. Cruising, which is deadly and fun since for no reason at you can be cruising at a great speed (you think) then are knocked out of your cruise mode by pirates wanting you dead even if they are in no way a threat.  Or there are T-gates! Think stargate and that is exactly it, you anchor at the place and for a modest fee, travel in safety from one end of space to another point in space! T-gates are almost always at a space station/planet you can dock at (if your faction rep says so) and are the safest (relatively) way to go long distances.  Then there are wormholes..... wormholes are kinda like t-gates, if t-gates were a game you pay for up front, wormholes are the f2p that suck you in and slowly rob you with you having no knowledge where you are going. They are free to use, but they will kill your troopers (dudes you have on board to steal ships or keep yours from being stolen) each time and break your ship a little. And when I said sucked in I mean they have a gravity well that pull you into it and spits you out of another one, which is great but that other one has a gravity well too that pulls you into it. If not careful and if there are different pairs of wormholes nearby you can end up alone on your now burning ship on the other side of the map not really wanting to try to return.   Lastly there is an item that lets your teleport your ship in a circular radius of map hexes based on how many you want to use at time. Only to hexes you have already been to, semi safe since you have no clue what is waiting for you, can get expensive (you need a massive amount of the already costly items to even trying moving halfway cross map) but you wont get jumped on route like in cruising so, win?Lastly for now is the level up process... You can get experience from quests (variable from oh, nice to meh), and pirati- I mean defending your local area from them pirates and invaders. What does it do? lets you level certain skills you have chosen based on a life style of play I do not think impacts game too greatly. Really for most of the area I forget to use the things until I am nearly dying and go Save Me Buttons!  And Perks, perks are like skills but they are not tied to the action skills, they are always active.   Skills and Perks I think would be more impacting if they were not so dang situational, the buttons are very much a maybe use. Perks are very tied to certain aspects of the game, but are not acquired quickly enough to even remember to check for them. Or feel like they even do much when used.  It is a nice, balanced feature, but when you are able to reset your skills and perks the choices are less impacting on your decision time. I still am very happy I spent the cash on it, and if you like SPESS PIRATEZ, then you can be one in this one.  I do hope they keep this mode active if they come out with a story mode too.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Really impressed! It plays like a mix of Freelancer, X3 and Eve. It's super intuitive to pick up and play and the menus are all neatly laid out and self explanatory without sacrificing your ability to do what you need to do. Combat varies depending on the ship but for the most part it's slower than the frantic arcade dogfights seen in Chris Roberts games; with more emphasis on positioning and presenting sides of your ship to enemy.Trading and economy functions as you'd expect, with goods costing more or less dependant on their origins and the political affiliations. There's a fair amount of contraband so it's best not to use the "Loot All" button if you're trying to live a virtuous life.In terms of Early Access content; the game feels very polished already with much of the world content seemingly in place and all game systems working as you'd expect. The current starting scenario is possibly a little bit easy, starting you off as it does with a mid level ship and plenty of tools already at your disposal. The missions are all randomly generatied (apparently depending on your actions, though I've yet to make a big enough impact on my galaxy to see this) and most of them follow a fairly standard template. It'd be nice for some more intensive missions with multiple stages but the ones that are there give you enough to do, and when they involve going through hostile areas they can become quite harrowing. The full game will have a story mode, which isn't present in this E.A release, so who knows what that will entail.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												This is (in my opinion) one of the greater games on Steam. For those who are looking for a TASTE of EVE here you go. This game is almost like a baby stepping stone into the EVE universe. While the game does have its flaws as I will state, I believe that this sandbox game has great potental. Now, I will say that I do not believe it is worth $40 just yet. The modding community has yet to take off and you can cheat the game by simply opening your save in Notepad++ and editing the data. Which I believe somewhat cuts the fun out of comparing achievements to other players globally. The missions of hunting the heros are somewhat wonky as well because it seems they jump systems if you watch the map. Just as well, there is a very large difficulty spike in the game that you must prepare for. As you reach a certain level your enemies gain vet rank and you probably have yet to make enough money to even afford a ship that can stand up to them. (Unless you did what I do and stole a ship from the pirates) Now for the positives. This game has BEAUTIFUL scenery. For an indie game, a lot of time was put into this game and its atmosphere. The story and voice acting are a bit stale, but the fact that they are there is awesome. And the story, while being a bit dry, actually does make some form of sense. So kudos! At the start of the game you may pick to be a captain, engineer or another class that excels in firing. You may hire mercenaries to board ships or even follow you in to battle which is what the captains perks stand for. The shooter class perks somwhat speaks for itself. But I played as an engineer as the perks seemed to outweigh the others. The story is the same regardless of your class, but each class has its own specialties with 4 main "moves" But those moves have 5 evolutions within each allowing you to alter them as you go to tailor your playstyle up to the max level of 80. There are a plethora of planets to explore as well as tons of ships to purchase and try out. All in all, if you enjoy sandbox style games and as well as enjoy the beauty of flight or space travel, I recommend this game. I also recommend trying it if your thinking about EVE online. This game is a MUCH simpler thing. But it has many of the same aspects as well as can help you decide if you would even enjoy the simple aspects of what EVE offers before you worry about the more complex matters.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												This games is awesome, hands down. You pilot a ship, it starts out a bit small but you can get very large ones. The thing that makes this game awesome is that you can just go anywhere and do anything. There is a story mode but it's not really important or vital to follow, I have mostly ignored it so far. Combat is a lot of fun, there is no "strategic pausing" or anything to strategize, and you really have a ton of stuff to micromanage. That said, your mechanical ability to think quickly, pilot your ship, use items/abilities, and position properly have HUGE outcomes on the combat. If you're good, you can do a lot with a little ship, if you're bad you can to little with a big ship. Combat is definitely an extremely fun aspect in this game but there is also so much more than just fighting other ships. The exploration in this game is really amazing. The landmarks (stations, planets, asteroid field locations etc) are static, everything else, the quests, the enemies, etc are completely random. You can pick a direction, put all power to engines, and fly to your hearts content. I actually spent an hour flying completely off the map. There isn't really anything noticeable out there except for a few enemies and such but it  definitely took me an hour to fly back. So yea, the exploration aspect in this game is huge, think skyrim in space but no drauger. So yea, awesome space battles, great exploration in a beautiful backdrop, it's really a lot of fun. The icing on the cake is the soundtrack. It's just ambient electronic but man it sets the mood well. I swear, this is the most relaxing game to play. Just mine asteroids, listen to the music, and be wisked away to a whole other solar system.Anyway, if you like exploring, enjoy space, and like relaxing for hours on end running cargo, hunting pirates, and looking at stars, you'll like this game.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												I obtained this game in early April 2016 during a great sale. The TL;DR is this: simple enough to pick up, complex enough not to put down. For me The game is marred only by its poor save mechanic and truly terrible voice acting. I was a bit surprised at how good this game was. Others have called it “Eve Light” and guess what? Its good enough comparison. Like other games such as “evochron Mercenary”, the Various “X” games like X3:Terren Conflict” , Freelancer etc, you fly around and do stuff for folks and get money from that. You can mine, salvage, build an economic power house, play taxi, attack the meannies, etc. What sets this game apart from the rest is a mix of easier to use controls, a good mix of things to do, good pace and an active community. If you think many space games are just too complicated without a joystick and throttle then you may like this game. Since I am not a pilot in real life, do not have a us$200 joystick, and have no desire to learn an intricate set of controls, I think this game is much easier to play and enjoy then many others of the same genre. Pros-	Controls are easy to learn but hard to master without needing an expensive joystick and throttle-	Enough choice to feel in control-	Good selection of mission types-	Fun achievements-	Good mix of things to do-	Fun exploration-	Developers are active in the community-	Enjoyable forum community-	Single player offline goodness. -	Survives repeated alt-tabbing out of the game.-	A slower pace then some space games -	Enough choices to feel in control without being so overwhelmed that you cant wrap your head around where to even begin-	Long tutorial campaign is kind of fun but not mandatory you can start it and pick the main campaign back up when you want to. Cons-	Really poor voice acting. Seriously BAD. Its cringe worthy how poor the voice acting is. -	Poor save game mechanic you can’t just save when you want to.  you’ll have to fly back to a station so its not the right choice for busy life if you can’t set aside a block of play time. This sis not a game that you can start to play if there is much chance of interruption since you may often find you cant save for another 5 or 10 minutes. -	Boring choice of ships in the start – just your own ship, nothing compares for some time into the game. There is nothing wrong with your starting ship but you can’t just swap it out for another other until much later in the game the other choices are simply too weak compared to what you start out using. -	Often inscrutable choices – you’ll need to use google allot to get a hang of what is going on. It’s a good thing that alt-tab does not break the game. It is a good thing the community is so active and there is plenty of information out there. -	Tutorial is bit thin you’ll need to google allot. it will help if you have played other space games like Eve Online, Freelancer, etc before this game.-	If you have played other space sims and want an immersive dog fighting, pirating power house this is not the right game for you.-	Single player may be a snooze fest if you are used to the pace of online games

Posted: April 3, 2016
												It's a space sim.If you expect soul-mouving roleplay or vast army battles or deep scale business management, you'll be disapopointed cause... it's a space sim.It's a pretty darn good space sim at that. It's pretty, atmospheric and quite fun to play.  There are a few bugs still out there but nothing major, nothing to break the game.  The map is huge.  You have good control over your ship and character. There are more factions than you need and there's always stuff happening.  Nothing heavilly scripted, it's all pretty much standard space sim missions.  Destroy that guy, smuggle this, escort that, repair this, explore that. You know.  Space sim.The voice acting is abysmal.  So abysmal, it's awesome.  Honestly, it feels like a game made by people who have a lot of love for the genre.  I expect to spend many, many more hours exploring space. I just throw a few Malcolm Reynolds one liners here and there and suddenly, I'm in space, doing space stuff. I'm cool like that. (I may or may not be taking meds regarding this)Oh and the music... I would have bought the game for the music alone.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												First off: I like this game quite a bit. It is neither too expensive, nor bad looking or somehow broken or buggy.This is a first impressions, not a 100% review, because the game is huge.The good stuff:- Fly around in space in your own "capital" ship. I put that in quotes, because your first ship is a small semi-freighter whatever, but packs quite a punch. Apparently you can go all the way up to cruisers, destroyers, carriers and stuff.- Simple, yet efficient trading system (X3 would have done good to use that). You can see all available goods for trade as well as best buy and sell prices on the star map and can automaticall plot a course to the desired station.- Space looks good. Graphics are really not all that bad.- Combat is interesting in a sense that it's a mix between flying and shooting yourself and also using several skills to enhance damage, survivability etc. I'd just have hoped to have more interesting skills to use. You can also use items and fire your heavy guns like missiles etc. The coolest part, however, is to just have your turrets fire automatically while you concentrate on evading. This is not advised 100% of the time, but it's neat. Turrets will also have fire arcs to take into account. You can easily see the status of your shields and hull and can high tail it out of a fight with max engine power. You can also distribute power between engines, shields and weapons, so that is all very solid if basic (whoever played Freespace 2 for example knows what I mean). I would have liked to redistribute power from my forward shields to my rearward shields for example or have some sort of pause mode where I could issue my gunners or fighters to target a certain area of a ship. Either I just have not found a way to pause the game (because I see comments that it was supposed to be a thing) or it isn't there. I also don't know if you can target different subsystems on a ship. So far I have found an option to target "ship systems", but not individual ones. It would have been great to target a ship's engines or weapons individually to disable it, but I guess that would be a task better suited to fighters than capital ships. There are apparently also boarding torpedoes so you can take over enemy ships. The weapon types encompass all you really need, from railguns, to beams, plasma weapons, rockets and torpedoes. I'd just look forward to getting a bigger ship, but the only bigger thing I see costs a million credits and money is hard to come by if you don't invest a lot of time into trade or something like that. The cruiser even costs 15 million! Long way to go.- The map is huge and full of different factions and pirates.The not so good stuff:- You can apparently only have control over 1 ship (and some mercs) but not command your own fleet (maybe in an expansion or so I've heard), which is kind of disappointing, but ok. - Automated freighters. I don't see a possibility to have those either. You can own different ships, yes, but there seems to be no way to assign a freighter to go trading on his own in order to generate money while you do something more interesting, because seriously...trading is great and all but it IS extremely boring to have to fly the routes yourself every time...that is a ♥♥♥♥ing slow way of making money...but I think you can have stations or something like that at least...- The flight distance. Crossing from one point of the map to the other could potentially take a looooong time. There are fast travel routes, but those cost money...lots of money as far as I can see...that kinda sucks. There are also worm holes at least.- The campaign is...ugh...so utterly boring thus far? Go here, collect a core here, help this dude we totally don't even know or get to know...destroy a ship, bam 30 secs, go back...and all the while suffering through the TERRIBLE dialogue...I'm sorry, but this is definitely the weakest part of the game. Especially the main character just does not have an enticing voice to listen to in a game. Some spoken dialogue is even missing lol.- Scale. The fighting is a bit weird sometimes, because you don't even see a lot of the enemies you are shooting. At least not in the earlier stages of the game. Keeping track of multiple enemies in a fight is painful, because your automated gunners will not necessarily target your target, but whatever they damn well please. Also, the fighting is kind of weird some times. I've encountered an enemy that was apparently "impossible" for me to take on according to the game. I was level 1. I killed it. By staying on its tail and out of the reach of its main guns...really? ;) That was kind of anticlimactic...- Weapons and ships. I can currently buy some different ships and lots of different weapons systems and stuff, but it all seems worse than what I have, so either the game is not good at giving me information or there is no purpose in me buying new stuff. For example, I can buy a gunship for about 250k. That gunship has less hps than my starting ship, cannot carry missiles and has less power available, so why would I buy that? Also most weapons systems seem to deal less damage than what I have installed. That is weird.- Contraband. I once picked up illegal drugs from a destroyed ship. I was told I was entering an area where these drugs are illegal. I sold them. Nothing happened. Why can I sell this stuff at a station in a system where the drug is supposedly illegal? I don't get it.So, take everything with a grain of salt, but I'd say the game is definitely worth the asking price. If I had to rate it I would give it a solid 80+ I'd say. It does what it says it would do. It controls nicely, looks good and thus far I have not encountered any real bugs. There is always room for improvements and I hope an expansion or dlc will come out.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												While I've played this a ton over past 2 weeks, was very tough call on whether to recommend this for others.Pros:- Generally entertaining, I love the premise of an open-world space sim in general- Good performance & interesting visuals (no sigificant lag or graphics issues on my rig with GTX770)- Enjoyed exploring and "freeroam" option to explore galaxy & amass wealth as I desired- Fair amount of flexibility to do different activities such as trading, mining, fighting pirates, capturing ships, smuggling & choose to side with "good" or "bad" factionsCons:- Capturing vastly overpowered for gathering wealth quickly, breaks scaling- Enemies scale ... inconsistantly ... with your level & ship power, if don't gather a lot of wealth early can be very rough- Lots of late game special add-ons not quite working right yet / buggy (blueprints) and take a ton of work to collect- You can't actually land or explore planets (just get same menu interface as at any shipyard by clicking on it)- Factions vastly simplified, no complex interactions (while having something like 20+ factions, they all break down into 3 options: the hate everyone factions, the good factions, and the evil factions)- Also, as a "space sim" I find it extremely jarring from immersion that it disregards most aspects of physics as they operate in our universe (severe viloations or completely ignoring gravity with all objects permanently hung in same spots in space & no orbital mechanics observed at all, relative sizes/scale of objects at distance are wildly inconsistant and in particular planets are massively distorted relative to distance and relative to stars, optics of light/dark side of planets not shown, vacuum transmits sound, no conservation of momentum, space completely littered with stationary debris everywhere)Basically if you love the idea of an open world single player space sim with some very light RPG elements in upgrades/statistics, you might find this entertaining for a while as I did.  If looking for a movie-like story, or any realism in economics, politics/diplomacy, or physics, or multi-player options, or longer term RPG depth, you won't find it here.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												**UPDATE**(9/30/14)The game is now at full release. I will break the game into categories below and comment my opinion on them.(+ means positive, * means neutral, - means negative)Gameplay:+Fast, exciting and action packed combat+Plenty of ship customization+Controls are fairly intuitive and easy to use+Plenty to explore and collect+Moddability*RPG style progression (skilltree and leveling)*Unrealistic physics makes things easier to play but undesirable to some*No multiplayer-Limited to 3 class choice on start of new game, cannot change later-Unrealistic scale of universe (mainly planets and stars are WAY too small)-No docking animation for stations-Occasional crashesStory:*Typical story, nothing special-Bad voice acting/racial steriotypes detract from story-Some missions "vanish" from map meaning you must load old save to continue storyGraphics/Sound:+Good quality graphics and visuals+Good sound effects and music overall-FPS takes a large hit during a few mission scenes or large battles-Aforementioned poor voice acting-Visual bugs with space background images (visible "skyboxes") are occasionally seenOverall Impression:This game has been quite a fun experience coming from a fan of RPG style games. The level progression system and skilltree coupled with a highly moddable ship means you have a reason to keep playing and improving. You are able to pilot anything from a tiny gunship to a powerful carrier but do not expect to be a fleet commander. Emphasis on is your ship. The story gives you a reason to play but it is not where the game shines. The most fun to be had is exploring, lucrative bounties and close encounters with tough enemies. Its a shame the game crashes on occassion and the story has some bugs. These things will hopefully be ironed out soon.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you enjoyed Freelancer or the X series, you will probably like this game too.It took me about 30 minutes or so to figure out what the hell I was doing. The tutorial was decent, if intrusive (you can turn it off and access it later), and gives you a basic run down of how to control your ship, and some information on the various HUD icons and such. After that, its up to you to explore and play around with things. The (arguably) nice thing about this game is that, unlike the X series, it seems difficult, if not impossible, to fatally screw up in the early stages of your game.Give that this is early access, there are, of course, some issues:  Choppy performance - I bold this because it made the game very difficult to play. I am not sure if its simply my machine, or if others are experiencing it too, but it is a tad annoying.  Enemies are too easy - I am not sure whether they get more difficult as you play and level up. At the moment, if feels somewhat final fantasy-ish in that early enemies are deliberately easier to give the player time to power up and such before throwing them to the wolves. If that is the case, then cool I suppose, but right now, given how easily I seem to be able to wipe the asteroid belt with these pirate's ships, I'm not sure why anyone would pick a fight with me at this point.  Weird random graphical bugs - Whilst switching from auto to manual targetting, suddenly thousands of beam weapon streams fired out from my ship, followed my curser wherever it went. Looked cool though.  Lack of clear explanations - It took me a little bit to figure out what the different colours on various commodity prices actually meant. Yes, I did assume that red meant something bad (probably a bad selling price) and green was good, but it would be nice to have a tooltip, or something, to confirm my gamer's hypothesis. I'm still not certain what yellow means.  Probably some other issues I've either forogtten, or those I"ll encounter as I play...Despite the issues mentioned, I think this will turn out to be a really awesome game. I'm quite impressed with what the developers have done so far, and look forward to more updates.

												I'm only an hour or so in, but already I have that feeling as with many games I've loved over the years. Love the size of the system, love the campaign mode, love the visuals... combat is great fun and the addition of expendable modules is really clever. The Fleet isn't that well expanded on, I don't quite understand how best to use them or how to upgrade them.The way you access menus is fantastically intuitive, I didn't need a tutorial (which come thick and fast without any real sense of being anchored to what you're doing in-game) to reload weapons or move cargo, the buttons were just... where they should be.EDIT: Three hours in and still loving it. Worked out a few more of the game mechanics (loving the tactical overlay which you have to manually map, I have it on left-shift) and realised that I don't have a fleet yet! The RPG-lite elements are great, incremental improvements on all sorts of things means you have to really put some thought into what gameplay you want to get involved in. At this stage, unsure if it was wise to go with campaign mode, I think this could be even better in pure sandbox.

Early Access Review
								[Please note: I'm reviewing the Beta, played a few hours so far]You liked Freelancer, you like the (working) parts of the X-universe? You like to cloak your ship, sneak upon enemies, beam your crew abord and capture their vessels just to sell them at the next starbase? Then you should consider to buy Starpoint Gemini 2. It's just the far better game in comparision to the newest X-Game (and it's a little cheaper I guess).It's kind of different as well: you can slide your energy to different systems on the fly (i.e. shields and weapons), you can upgrade your ships systems one by one, you have a decent skilltree as far as I took a look and the performance is good so far -at least for a beta, what you really should have in mind. If you are willing to take a second for the game to load in new sectors the game runs just fine (on my system at least: nvidia 760,8gig,phenomII).Can't really say anything about trading though. I'm not much of a trader, but there are plenty of ships, stations and so on in which you can buy and sell stuff. What hits me is the option to smuggle: you got illegal stuff from the pirate you just blew up? Smuggle it on a planet and make some profit! :DWell, let's talk about the downs as well: Sure, there are some missions. Kill that, transport that, press a button to repair a station, look for a vessel in distress and so on. But there is quite a lack of background to me. Sure, nice music does a lot, but I didn't run into any NPCs/dialogues so far.______I strongly recommend the game at this point, I really did not regret to back up the developers here like I did with the newest X (yeah, you see, can't even remember it's name....aww god, I hate it so much xD).

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is my early access review - I will change my review for the final product.If you love the Sci-fi and the adventure of exploring space - particularly Star Trek, Babylon 5, or Star Wars - you will absolutely love this game! It's truly a unique space sim/rpg experience, and this is the first game that has done justice to this genre I believe. The universe is your sandbox, and you're free to do whatever you want - trade, mine asteroids, hunt down criminals, or take part in space battles - take command and boldly go into the beautiful, yet dangerous, reaches of space. - So far the graphics are excellent; the art style is beatiful; ship designs are unique, yet they will remind you of your favorite Sci'fi. At the moment, I'm flying a ship that reminds me of a Tau Empire or a Homeworld Kadeshi ship - love it. Being able to customize and design your weapon systems, costmetic look of your ship, and having access to a wide range of various kinds of ships, is the best feature of the game for me. Working to get that special ship you always wanted - whether it be a large Carrier class that can launch swarming fighters/bombers; a massive heavily armed Dreadnought armed to the teeth with Missile Launcers and Rail Guns; a swift Gunship or Corevette, decked out in Plasma Cannons; or a stealthy fighter class with cloaking - is all possible for you here.  - Music is atmospheric, and fits the setting perfectly - although, I would like to hear an extended soundtrack in the finished product, or post-launch. - Combat Missions are fun, and Space combat is the by far the best part of the game. Scientific explorations; Repairing Space stations, Science Vessels/outposts, or even Space prisons, is a nice touch to fill in the world, and make it feel like you're in a living universe. Although, there is need for more variations in these missions; though this is early access, and there is still more content in the works to make the universe feel more alive, and give you more to do as you explore. The game may be early access, but it's very well made in every way so far - I can only imagine how good the finished product will be. The Developers are the most friendly, and helpful ones I ever came across; they're transparent in their work on the game, and very open in sharing ideas with fans and are open to suggestions and feedback. This is a top notch game in it's genre; and both this game, and it's fantastic devs, deserve your support. Starpoint Gemini 2 has an exciting future, and I'm glad I've taken part in it's journey.

If you are willing to take a second for the game to load in new sectors the game runs just fine (on my system at least: nvidia 760,8gig,phenomII).Can't really say anything about trading though. I'm not much of a trader, but there are plenty of ships, stations and so on in which you can buy and sell stuff. What hits me is the option to smuggle: you got illegal stuff from the pirate you just blew up? Smuggle it on a planet and make some profit! :DWell, let's talk about the downs as well: Sure, there are some missions. Kill that, transport that, press a button to repair a station, look for a vessel in distress and so on. But there is quite a lack of background to me. Sure, nice music does a lot, but I didn't run into any NPCs/dialogues so far.______I strongly recommend the game at this point, I really did not regret to back up the developers here like I did with the newest X (yeah, you see, can't even remember it's name....aww god, I hate it so much xD).

Early Access Review
								This is my early access review - I will change my review for the final product.If you love the Sci-fi and the adventure of exploring space - particularly Star Trek, Babylon 5, or Star Wars - you will absolutely love this game! It's truly a unique space sim/rpg experience, and this is the first game that has done justice to this genre I believe. The universe is your sandbox, and you're free to do whatever you want - trade, mine asteroids, hunt down criminals, or take part in space battles - take command and boldly go into the beautiful, yet dangerous, reaches of space. - So far the graphics are excellent; the art style is beatiful; ship designs are unique, yet they will remind you of your favorite Sci'fi. At the moment, I'm flying a ship that reminds me of a Tau Empire or a Homeworld Kadeshi ship - love it. Being able to customize and design your weapon systems, costmetic look of your ship, and having access to a wide range of various kinds of ships, is the best feature of the game for me. Working to get that special ship you always wanted - whether it be a large Carrier class that can launch swarming fighters/bombers; a massive heavily armed Dreadnought armed to the teeth with Missile Launcers and Rail Guns; a swift Gunship or Corevette, decked out in Plasma Cannons; or a stealthy fighter class with cloaking - is all possible for you here.  - Music is atmospheric, and fits the setting perfectly - although, I would like to hear an extended soundtrack in the finished product, or post-launch. - Combat Missions are fun, and Space combat is the by far the best part of the game. Scientific explorations; Repairing Space stations, Science Vessels/outposts, or even Space prisons, is a nice touch to fill in the world, and make it feel like you're in a living universe. Although, there is need for more variations in these missions; though this is early access, and there is still more content in the works to make the universe feel more alive, and give you more to do as you explore. The game may be early access, but it's very well made in every way so far - I can only imagine how good the finished product will be. The Developers are the most friendly, and helpful ones I ever came across; they're transparent in their work on the game, and very open in sharing ideas with fans and are open to suggestions and feedback. This is a top notch game in it's genre; and both this game, and it's fantastic devs, deserve your support. Starpoint Gemini 2 has an exciting future, and I'm glad I've taken part in it's journey.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												First off: I like this game quite a bit. It is neither too expensive, nor bad looking or somehow broken or buggy.This is a first impressions, not a 100% review, because the game is huge.The good stuff:- Fly around in space in your own "capital" ship. I put that in quotes, because your first ship is a small semi-freighter whatever, but packs quite a punch. Apparently you can go all the way up to cruisers, destroyers, carriers and stuff.- Simple, yet efficient trading system (X3 would have done good to use that). You can see all available goods for trade as well as best buy and sell prices on the star map and can automaticall plot a course to the desired station.- Space looks good. Graphics are really not all that bad.- Combat is interesting in a sense that it's a mix between flying and shooting yourself and also using several skills to enhance damage, survivability etc. I'd just have hoped to have more interesting skills to use. You can also use items and fire your heavy guns like missiles etc. The coolest part, however, is to just have your turrets fire automatically while you concentrate on evading. This is not advised 100% of the time, but it's neat. Turrets will also have fire arcs to take into account. You can easily see the status of your shields and hull and can high tail it out of a fight with max engine power. You can also distribute power between engines, shields and weapons, so that is all very solid if basic (whoever played Freespace 2 for example knows what I mean). I would have liked to redistribute power from my forward shields to my rearward shields for example or have some sort of pause mode where I could issue my gunners or fighters to target a certain area of a ship. Either I just have not found a way to pause the game (because I see comments that it was supposed to be a thing) or it isn't there. I also don't know if you can target different subsystems on a ship. So far I have found an option to target "ship systems", but not individual ones. It would have been great to target a ship's engines or weapons individually to disable it, but I guess that would be a task better suited to fighters than capital ships. There are apparently also boarding torpedoes so you can take over enemy ships. The weapon types encompass all you really need, from railguns, to beams, plasma weapons, rockets and torpedoes. I'd just look forward to getting a bigger ship, but the only bigger thing I see costs a million credits and money is hard to come by if you don't invest a lot of time into trade or something like that. The cruiser even costs 15 million! Long way to go.- The map is huge and full of different factions and pirates.The not so good stuff:- You can apparently only have control over 1 ship (and some mercs) but not command your own fleet (maybe in an expansion or so I've heard), which is kind of disappointing, but ok. - Automated freighters. I don't see a possibility to have those either. You can own different ships, yes, but there seems to be no way to assign a freighter to go trading on his own in order to generate money while you do something more interesting, because seriously...trading is great and all but it IS extremely boring to have to fly the routes yourself every time...that is a ♥♥♥♥ing slow way of making money...but I think you can have stations or something like that at least...- The flight distance. Crossing from one point of the map to the other could potentially take a looooong time. There are fast travel routes, but those cost money...lots of money as far as I can see...that kinda sucks. There are also worm holes at least.- The campaign is...ugh...so utterly boring thus far? Go here, collect a core here, help this dude we totally don't even know or get to know...destroy a ship, bam 30 secs, go back...and all the while suffering through the TERRIBLE dialogue...I'm sorry, but this is definitely the weakest part of the game. Especially the main character just does not have an enticing voice to listen to in a game. Some spoken dialogue is even missing lol.- Scale. The fighting is a bit weird sometimes, because you don't even see a lot of the enemies you are shooting. At least not in the earlier stages of the game. Keeping track of multiple enemies in a fight is painful, because your automated gunners will not necessarily target your target, but whatever they damn well please. Also, the fighting is kind of weird some times. I've encountered an enemy that was apparently "impossible" for me to take on according to the game. I was level 1. I killed it. By staying on its tail and out of the reach of its main guns...really? ;) That was kind of anticlimactic...- Weapons and ships. I can currently buy some different ships and lots of different weapons systems and stuff, but it all seems worse than what I have, so either the game is not good at giving me information or there is no purpose in me buying new stuff. For example, I can buy a gunship for about 250k. That gunship has less hps than my starting ship, cannot carry missiles and has less power available, so why would I buy that? Also most weapons systems seem to deal less damage than what I have installed. That is weird.- Contraband. I once picked up illegal drugs from a destroyed ship. I was told I was entering an area where these drugs are illegal. I sold them. Nothing happened. Why can I sell this stuff at a station in a system where the drug is supposedly illegal? I don't get it.So, take everything with a grain of salt, but I'd say the game is definitely worth the asking price. If I had to rate it I would give it a solid 80+ I'd say. It does what it says it would do. It controls nicely, looks good and thus far I have not encountered any real bugs. There is always room for improvements and I hope an expansion or dlc will come out.

												While I've played this a ton over past 2 weeks, was very tough call on whether to recommend this for others.Pros:- Generally entertaining, I love the premise of an open-world space sim in general- Good performance & interesting visuals (no sigificant lag or graphics issues on my rig with GTX770)- Enjoyed exploring and "freeroam" option to explore galaxy & amass wealth as I desired- Fair amount of flexibility to do different activities such as trading, mining, fighting pirates, capturing ships, smuggling & choose to side with "good" or "bad" factionsCons:- Capturing vastly overpowered for gathering wealth quickly, breaks scaling- Enemies scale ... inconsistantly ... with your level & ship power, if don't gather a lot of wealth early can be very rough- Lots of late game special add-ons not quite working right yet / buggy (blueprints) and take a ton of work to collect- You can't actually land or explore planets (just get same menu interface as at any shipyard by clicking on it)- Factions vastly simplified, no complex interactions (while having something like 20+ factions, they all break down into 3 options: the hate everyone factions, the good factions, and the evil factions)- Also, as a "space sim" I find it extremely jarring from immersion that it disregards most aspects of physics as they operate in our universe (severe viloations or completely ignoring gravity with all objects permanently hung in same spots in space & no orbital mechanics observed at all, relative sizes/scale of objects at distance are wildly inconsistant and in particular planets are massively distorted relative to distance and relative to stars, optics of light/dark side of planets not shown, vacuum transmits sound, no conservation of momentum, space completely littered with stationary debris everywhere)Basically if you love the idea of an open world single player space sim with some very light RPG elements in upgrades/statistics, you might find this entertaining for a while as I did.  If looking for a movie-like story, or any realism in economics, politics/diplomacy, or physics, or multi-player options, or longer term RPG depth, you won't find it here.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Starpoint Gemini 2 is to space exploration games what Skyrim is to fantasy adventure games. Vast, full of lore and play styles and activities for everyone, and just so beautiful to stroll through and appreciate the scenery. The long list of buttons and actions appear daunting at first, but are easy to learn and facilitate a rich level of interactivity that makes an enjoyable experience for both the casual gamer and the hardcore strategist. Stats, activities and tricks offer a healthy challenge for micromanagement fiends, and movement and combat are simple yet satisfying enough for someone who has an actual job and no time to micromanage in a virtual world. Also like in Skyrim, the voice acting is endearing and the accents are so thick you could cut through them with a knife. It's not often I play a game with just the right balance of exploration, story, environment, gameplay and general polish that I don't mind playing all day on a day off. Also like with Skyrim, STEAM WORKSHOP! Can't wait to find some funny mods in the future. Little Green Men Games nailed it. 10/10, would buy for the wife and kids.

Posted: March 10, 2015
												Did you like Privateer and Freelancer?  Did you read the reviews comparing this game to those, as well as Outlaw Star and other anime classics?  Don't believe them!  I did and I regret it.  If you like tutorials that are either outdated and no longer have any bearing on the game, or "tutorials" that are nothing more that a summary of key bindings, this game is for you.  (By the way, anyone who points out the shortcomings and is desperate to learn how to play the game they just bought are often derided as 5 year old simpletons in their tutorial forums.)Combat system is a joke:  The manual controls are wonky and attempting to manually control flight will send your ship into endless oscillations and fishtails.  If you let the computer take over this function by using the fire at will command, the ship stands still and shoots randomly at enemys off the edge of the screen, occasionally getting a hit but never resolving combat.  (I tried this, walked away for 1/2 hour, came back and it was still randomly firing at the same enemy with no real damage to my ship or theirs.)Don't care about combat and want to be a trader?  Good luck!  When you try to go somewhere, you are ambushed and drawn into combat, resulting in the frustration loop that I described above.Feels like an Alpha.  Despite what the developers say, this game is unplayable.  It has too many rough edges and still needs alot of work.Don't buy it.  I did and I regret it.Spend your money on X3, or some other legitimate franchise.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												After a few hours in freeroam I feel like I've experience enough of Starpoint Gemini 2 to review it. First of all, this is mostly a classic space sim when playing in freeroam. It's mining/trading/mercenary grind to get better equipment and ships but it has some differences - there's skill points and experience levels, which is nice if you enjoy playing RPG's (I do)You don't start in fighter class ships. In fact - you can't fly the fighter class ships. You start in a Gunship class ship (or above if you have the DLC's). Your crew can man the turret hardpoints for you, and you will want them to. They are perfect shots every time. The turret AI is *very* good. You don't need to concentrate on weapons except to line up for heavy weapon shots, which are ammo limited but deal more damage per shot than your turrets. But....you probably won't even have to use them. Starpoint Gemini 2 has a problem if you're a pilot who knows basic concepts of space sim combat. If you can assess firing arcs, manage shield energy and experience in MMO type skill buffs, normal difficulty is a relaxing grind even if you take assassination missions 6 to 10 levels above your level. Most enemy ships don't have cloak scanners, so you can drop out and unleash hell with an undetected approach and take down "Deadly" and even with a little luck "Impossible" targets. This is a bit of a shame as this game wants to force you to fly combat role ships. I haven't seen ore freighters or transports. You can seemingly only buy Gunships and above with military kitting. Mining/Trading is viable but the cargo holds are disgustingly small and the mods that increase them in the workshop do not work with the DLC. You can not upgrade cargo capacity. If you're a frieghter captain your best bet is to get something with the biggest hold in the class which is marginally bigger than the rest and prepare to make MANY trips to and from asteroids and debris fields. Which is also a bit strange - asteroid and debris fields are EVERYWHERE, and you can't take advantage of it. Unfortunately most of the modders seem intent on putting in ridiculous godships instead of addressing the lack of civilian vessels. I usually like to play as a frieghter captain, in my game now I'm just a mercenary taking contracts well above my level for the massive increase in EXP and Credits. Overall I'm very pleased with this game. It's very underrated. I can expect I'll be putting many many more hours into it, as I have with X. This isn't Starpoint Gemini 1 for sure, and it's not the mess that is Star Wolves. It's not X either, but it's a better game than say Tachyon or Darkstar One and a nice alternative. Haven't played story yet. Not sure I will. Also this game and the Rebel Galaxy soundtrack works very nicely together. 10/10 Exploded a frigate as a gunship by exploiting cloak and firing arcs.

Posted: November 10, 2014
												Firstly, understand that although my review will say I've only logged 9 hours on this game, it's more like 20 because I played a lot in offline mode.This game is beautiful, both visually and with the music. But other than some eye candy and a few atmospheric soundtracks it doesn't feel like it has anything else going for it. Saving up for better ships is a slow grind, and combat becomes repetitive quickly. Once you get the better ships all you really accomplish is the ability to throw some more bullets/lasers at people at some different angles, but gameplay never fundamentally changes. Stronger enemies are just like the easier ones only they have more health and higher damage output, but you fight them all fundamentally the same way. The enemy AI is terrible; they have a self-preservation instinct akin to plastic ducks in a carnival shooting gallery. Killing enemies ranges from extremely easy to just downright tedious, but never feels challenging. The universe is clutterred with interesting stuff (real space doesn't have objects this close to each other) so there's no shortage of places to explore, but there's no real incentive to explore anything. One region might just be another solar system but with a blue nebula instead of a red one and the asteroids are made of some different resource. I'll give this game an alright/10. It's fun when you first pick it up, but playing for long periods will make the game stale quickly. I'm at a point where I want to play this game, but I just can't stomach flying around in space shooting at the same pirate ships to travel to some samey looking region- not for more than maybe 5 minutes at a time. I feel like there's nothing to do in this big universe the game presents. Hopefully the mod community will be able to salvage the game so I can feel like I got my money's worth.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												First off ignore my play time. I do most of my gaming at work and dont have an internet connection. Unfortunately Steam doesnt keep track of play time while in offline mode. As of writing this I have around 24 hours of gameplay in. In short this game is excellent and well worth the money.The universe is huge. And it would take a long while to fly from one side to the other. The ships are awesome. There is a lot to do.. You can be a trader, a pirate, a bounty hunter... The list goes on. It takes a lot of work to acquire new ships and level up. Not in a bad way.  I actually love it.. In my 24 hours of playtime I've only recently just captured a ship worth keeping and transferring to. Its not really grindy in my opinion as there is so much to do it seems you're all the time doing something different or new. I see that as a really good value for my money. I have only done 3 main/campaign quests at this point as you have to take time to level up and gear up for them. So its not a game you're going to beat within a few hours. Capturing ships better than yours is a real challenge and its very rewarding when you finally get one. So far Ive found capturing ships to be the funnest and most profitable thing to do. And when you finally get out of the starting gunship into something better it gets a little easier and much more profitable. The learning curve is easy. Not like learning X3 or anything. You can pick it up fairly quick.The game doesnt baby you.. You can run into a battleship that will destroy within minutes of starting the game so you always have to be careful and keep an eye out. There's always a challenge..It's not a game that will allow you to feel like a god that just steam rolls everything that comes along. I like that as it gives you something to strive for. However I will say now that I've gotten a better ship (Its a corvette btw) i come across a lot more ships that are weak or trivial. Its extremely cool when you come into an area with a bunch of them.. I just turn on Auto fire and watch my ship just destroy 5 or 6 ships within minutes.. It's awesome.So far the only things that Ive found to be less than great are the voice acting and traveling..The voice acting is far from good. Its not so bad that it destroys the campaign for you.. But its not good either lol. Your ships computer voice is great though and thats the one you'll hear 90% of the time. The traveling.. When you first start you dont really have a choice but to fly all the way to each location. As warp gates are expensive and not really an option at first. Worm holes do damage and really dont have enough of them to justify them as a good way to travel. Rifts help but they are kind of hard to stay in. So at first the traveling gets kind of old as the map is just so hufmge it can really take a long while to get from one point to another. But after you get a decent income going and you can afford the warp gates its not bad. All in all the game has been an excellent experience. And I feel the user rating should be quite a bit better than it is now. It's a game that I've quickly became addicted to and I already know I'll have hundreds of hours into before I get tired of it.If your looking for a good space rpg, sandbox, freelancer type game this one will not dissappoint.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Pros:-It's pretty straightforward and fun. You don't need a month to learn all the controls.-lots of ships to collect and fill your garage-upgrades and things to spend money on-pretty good atmospheric space with things in itCons:-the ships feel a little same-y. After progressing from gunship through cruiser so far, there's little real difference-the missions feel a little same-y, side quests are just the same as the randomly generated quests. Main quests are only slightly different so far.-no dynamic economy, at least as far as I can tell. Gods are such small money compared to capturing ships and doing missions that you'll find yourself just hitting'sell all' instead of telling around for best pricesThis closest game to compare I've played is x2. This stacks up as a much simplified relative. It's more fun much faster, but there's also less depth. In x2 I would leave my computer running all day with time compression on and come back to see how much money I'd made reading. A game that can pay itself, and you build in the means to speed it up, should probably put a little more focus on fun. But it also was a much more engaging dog fighter. Here ask guns are on turrets, so the most effective combat is to just set them on automatic. Not the most engaging. The capture mechanic is decent, better than the x2 random bail out thing. But you can't command your own fleet and start and trade empire or manufacturing empire. There just seen to be fee ways to interact with the world. You can shoot things, scan them, grapple them, shoot them... I like the grapple mechanic by the way. But the ships don't feel different and lack a grand sense of scale. So yeah it's fun to capture and collect a bunch of ships, but the upgrades are a little wonky and there's not a ton to do outside of that. The weapons can be upgraded and swapped out, but all the other systems on the ship are fixed and can only have upgrades added. Why can't I customize whether I wasn't cloaking or a hanger? Style of pay is dictated by ship choice, not Games are cool and the most fun when you feel like you're discovering something special. An abandoned derelict that you can salvage for special items? Or one that's functional and maybe had a special feature. Hidden upgrades, officers, unique items that you can find as you explore would all help the depth of the game world. Overall 7.5/10Fun, but comes across a little flat. Could use some flair to make it feel more special.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Don't be fooled by the 30 factions, there are essentially 2 - good or bad, and even then being "bad" is difficult due to how reputation is managed.The gameplay is alright, but the most effective way of making money is SLOWLY towing in captured ships to salvage them. Cargo is incredibly limited on anything but freighters, but why would you ever fly a freighter? There is no sandbox or dynamic economy to speak of, so there's not point in being a pacifist. Regions are locked to one faction, the map is entirely static and the campaign is laughable. Large ships are only marginally slower than tiny ships, and no ship ever reaches the size of even the smallest EVE Online capital ship, so piloting a "fighter" is essentially the same as a carrier.Still, I love this game.The music is fantastic, the fetch quests are in an atmospheric enough universe that I don't mind the skinner box, the modding tools seem to be very powerful so a few of these issues could (or are already fixed). The ships don't look all that great (I don't think any game is going to reach the same level of lore and style as EVE Online), but I still love piloting them.I love it, but I wouldn't recommend it if you don't have a specific itch.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												This game has come a LONG way since the pre-release versions. The story/campaign is filled out with good voiceovers and an interesting plot with tight mission mechanics. There are some very interesting and rewarding side quests. The sandbox random encounters and freelance missions are still there and very good. There are very few bugs, and the performance is outstanding.This game is much less ambitious than, say, Star Citizen, in scope. It is a fairly limited third-person arcade-ish space shooter and trading game. However, everything that it does, it does WELL. That's a very respectable trait of a game, in this day and age, where the tendency is to over-promise and under-deliver. Starpoint Gemini 2 is intended to be an enjoyable single-player space opera where you acquire resources, build a fleet, gain renown and reputation, help some factions and war against others, and complete a storyline -- kind of like Skyrim in space. In attempting to implement these goals, it succeeds at them extremely well. I can highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good space adventure, with graphics that are slightly above average for 2015 (though not cutting-edge), tight game mechanics, and an interesting main plot.

Early Access Review
								As it stands now, even in Beta, it's a gorgeus game, and you can have great fun with it if you are a fan of the X4 genre or the more arcadish space sims out there. Well worth the money asked for.But I feel it needs a little push in some directions. It can become much more than it is now, if given enough deep and polish. For instance, weapon stats are confusing, and they have no description. Uniqueness and a little story for each weapon/ship/commodity in the world would make it deeper. The huge starmap needs more deepness too, the different factions are not different enough, more involvement in each of them would make it more fun. You need to love some factions and hate others, to be really immersed in the world. Currently, there are only good guys, and bad guys. You shoot the bad guys, that's it :-). Voiceovers and images of the different factions are a must to achieve this.Balance is still a little off, but it's to be expected in beta after all. You can destroy large enemy ships (destroyers or battleships) with your starter ship, without much sweating, but overall it's very fun and asks you for fairly involved gameplay, you need to use special powers and equipment to see it through the large battles unscathed.I know for a fact that the team is constantly updating and expanding the game daily, so I have high hopes for it all to be fullfilled in the end.Must buy for every space combat, space trader lover out there!

Early Access Review
								Not a fanboy of this game, I just found it 2 days ago. It's still in beta and I'm pretty impressed. It obviously has a few little issues, but is really really stable for me and has great graphics and mostly good gameplay.I think it has potential and the best way fo describe the game - for me - is that it's somewhat like skyrim in space. The game obviously has huge influences from freelancer and elite from back in the day.Unfortunately along those lines I think getting mission after mission that appears randomly and is just spawned from a list of standard missions - the time for this kind of gameplay is over. This is no different than grabbing a dungeon RPG and only getting random encounters in the dungeons which spawn from a known list.I think the missions could be far more interesting but there needs to be more hand crafted missions for this to get the replayability that something like skyrim has.There are a few UI issues but they are minor nuisances more than anything.The AI is also needing some serious fixing, I got into the game and killed a "hero" in the first few minutes netting me 5 million credits which is a gigantic amount.I am totally looking forward to this release, the space flight and combat are fluid and fun.Definitely a thumbs up on this game, with the proviso that current beta issues are dealt with.*Hopefully* it's a must have game.

												I can only recommend this game for people who have no problem with simply flying around blowing things up and nothing else. Because that is essentially everything you will do in this game. Blow things up.Blow enemy ships up, blow wreckages up, blow asteroids up...The trading system is a bare bones basic "pick things up that enemies drop and sell them at the nearest station"Sometimes you might come across illegal goods that might have the local authorities in a hissy fit but thats about it. Theres no system in place to actually figure out the best place to sell your goods so trade routes are a chore and not really worth it.The graphics are really nice but poorly optimized and some of the graphics options are locked at "high" like ship details and cant be lowered.The balancing is also all over the place with alot of weaponsystems being rather useless (all beam weapons for example) compared to the railgun type wich obliterates everything. Also even thought you can hire mercenaries to fly with you for a ingame monthly fee it never feels like you are actually in command of a fleet... wich is another missed oportunity.All in all what this game lacks is content... alot of content and a healthy dose of polish. There is a really great game hiding in starpoint gemini 2 but it just doesnt has any meat on its bones.So at its current state i can only recommend this game to hardcore space sim lovers who are starved for a title where you controll a battleship instead of a flimsy little one man fightercraft.  If you feel like youre that type you will get a lot of optical diverse ship designs... Thought there is hope that the modding community will jump in and polish things up a bit.

content:
Posted: March 4
												I'm enjoying the game quite a bit because the graphics and core gameplay are enjoyable.  There's also a relaxed atmosphere to the game - I don't feel pressured into "grinding in order to get to the good part".  The story is decent and there's plenty of "flavor text",  galactic "news", and loads of other ships flying around that altogether make the game world feel alive.  The GUI is well-designed and easily accessable with the mouse - I don't even bother using the hotkeys 90% of the time.  This also means that learning to play the game does not require memorizing a bunch of hotkeys!The random mission system is better than average compared to other games in this genre.  Also, progression happens at whatever pace you choose - you can sit near a station and shoot asteroids in relative safety for small rewards, or you can do the level-adjusted missions for a modest reward at minimal risk, or you can rush straight to the hostile sectors and do missions 30 levels higher than your own.  Or you can skip the missions entirely and capture ships, selling them for massive profits if you have the skill to pull it off.On the negative side, the game's ambient music lacks variety, so it gets annoying quickly.  Also, the ship's computer sometimes repeats warnings more frequently than necessary, which is especially annoying if the shields repeatedly drop due to EMP effects.  These problems are simply fixed by adjusting the volume settings.  I recommend listening to some space ambient music on youtube/spotify/whatever.I bought the game and DLC ("gold pack"), and I feel like I got my money's worth.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is excellent.  I'm only a few hours into it and don't even know the full extent of what it has to offer, but even what I've seen so far is extremely well done.  The system is open.  The ships pilot well from the keyboard or the mouse (haven't tried using a flight stick, yet).  The customization is extensive.  Overall, I'd say it's extremely good as beta releases go.  That's not to say there isn't some room for improvement.  There is.  But, the overall state of the game is very good and shows great promise.As far as negatives go, I'd have to say the biggest one for me is that there is not enough feedback when your shots impact an enemy vessel, especially on beam weapons.  The beams fire out and follow your targeting cursor, so the actual firing is good and responsive.  But, even at near point blank ranges, there isn't much to let you know that your beams are impacting a solid object.  Even a sound effect would be nice, a sort of deep rumble or a sort of cutting sound as you hit the enemy hull.  Close up, it's not a big deal.  But, at long distances, you aren't sure if you're connecting and wind up squinting at the screen to watch the enemy shield indicator.As I said, overall, this game is excellent, and it's still in beta.  I suspect there will be a lot more in the way of improvements.  I got this for $16.74 when it went on sale, and I'd say it's well worth that price.  Knowing what I know about it now, I'd likely buy it at full price.  As Early Access or beta games go, this is among the best.  Give it a shot.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'll update my review as the game continues development.7/19/2014, First ImpressionsI bought Startpoint Gemini 2, in spite of not really caring too much for the first one, but since it was on sale, and since it seemed to be so popular, I thought I would give this development studio another shot.  So far, I am glad I did.  Being an early access game, I expected some features needing polishing, and other features not yet to be fully implemented, which indeed is the case at the time of this initial post.  Having said that, I must say I find the gameplay mechanics very interesting, and the combat compelling.  If you are a fan of the old "X" games (except for X: Rebirth), you'll find some familiar concepts such as trading and boarding.  I also enjoyed how functional the developers made their starmap, making it easy to find missions, side jobs, or other distractions, whilst providing a wealth of information such as reputation and factions of each sector.  My only complaint here, is the lack of a legend.  I hope, in the near future, that will be provided as an on/off toggle.The combat is fun and flexible.  With the ability to upgrade, enhance, or otherwise customise your ship, each ship type you are capable of flying provides a wealth of possible combat configurations to fit your playstyle, or to try out different tactics.  I found the tactical overlay in combat especially helpful, though I had to manually assign a hotkey for it.  Of course, being an early access game, there are several areas upon which they can improve, such as providing a text-based battle log, or some other method of communicating more detail on what exactly is happening.  For example, when targeting an enemy, you have no consistent view of their shields.  There is some kind of HUD element that pops up when you first target them, but it does not stay up, and there is no clue on how to consistently get the information available.  It would be nice to be able to see, at least, the target's shield status on a consistent basis.  Likewise, critical hits are communicated, but no details are provided, such as what systems were critically hit.The Skills & Perk system of your officer is pretty cool.  It adds a lot of depth by allowing skills to provide several affects at once, while at the same time keeping the amount of button mashing (or mouse clicking) to a minimum.I will say one thing in this "first impressions" entry, and that is I was disappointed at not being able to command a fleet whilst directly controlling a ship of my own.  It is my hope that the developers have plans to allow this, as some of the game menus and screens suggest (such as "fleet management"...implying the ability to manage more than one ship in your fleet).

												Awesome awesome game. Well worth playing. Much improved over the original game. Features a very decent free roaming space 4X style experience, that looks and feels great. Another thing that bothered me slightly was how the camera system could do with a 'free mode' where the mouse would actually turn the camera around your ship in 360 degrees. The standard camera views are very acceptable though, but battle fought using the auto-targeting system can get kind of chaotic. It's also chaotic in a very good way, combat in this game is one of it's strong points. All in all, very satisfied. With the current holiday sale offer, I'd probably pick it up right about now for added value.
