content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Pros:-It's pretty straightforward and fun. You don't need a month to learn all the controls.-lots of ships to collect and fill your garage-upgrades and things to spend money on-pretty good atmospheric space with things in itCons:-the ships feel a little same-y. After progressing from gunship through cruiser so far, there's little real difference-the missions feel a little same-y, side quests are just the same as the randomly generated quests. Main quests are only slightly different so far.-no dynamic economy, at least as far as I can tell. Gods are such small money compared to capturing ships and doing missions that you'll find yourself just hitting'sell all' instead of telling around for best pricesThis closest game to compare I've played is x2. This stacks up as a much simplified relative. It's more fun much faster, but there's also less depth. In x2 I would leave my computer running all day with time compression on and come back to see how much money I'd made reading. A game that can pay itself, and you build in the means to speed it up, should probably put a little more focus on fun. But it also was a much more engaging dog fighter. Here ask guns are on turrets, so the most effective combat is to just set them on automatic. Not the most engaging. The capture mechanic is decent, better than the x2 random bail out thing. But you can't command your own fleet and start and trade empire or manufacturing empire. There just seen to be fee ways to interact with the world. You can shoot things, scan them, grapple them, shoot them... I like the grapple mechanic by the way. But the ships don't feel different and lack a grand sense of scale. So yeah it's fun to capture and collect a bunch of ships, but the upgrades are a little wonky and there's not a ton to do outside of that. The weapons can be upgraded and swapped out, but all the other systems on the ship are fixed and can only have upgrades added. Why can't I customize whether I wasn't cloaking or a hanger? Style of pay is dictated by ship choice, not Games are cool and the most fun when you feel like you're discovering something special. An abandoned derelict that you can salvage for special items? Or one that's functional and maybe had a special feature. Hidden upgrades, officers, unique items that you can find as you explore would all help the depth of the game world. Overall 7.5/10Fun, but comes across a little flat. Could use some flair to make it feel more special.

												First off ignore my play time. I do most of my gaming at work and dont have an internet connection. Unfortunately Steam doesnt keep track of play time while in offline mode. As of writing this I have around 24 hours of gameplay in. In short this game is excellent and well worth the money.The universe is huge. And it would take a long while to fly from one side to the other. The ships are awesome. There is a lot to do.. You can be a trader, a pirate, a bounty hunter... The list goes on. It takes a lot of work to acquire new ships and level up. Not in a bad way.  I actually love it.. In my 24 hours of playtime I've only recently just captured a ship worth keeping and transferring to. Its not really grindy in my opinion as there is so much to do it seems you're all the time doing something different or new. I see that as a really good value for my money. I have only done 3 main/campaign quests at this point as you have to take time to level up and gear up for them. So its not a game you're going to beat within a few hours. Capturing ships better than yours is a real challenge and its very rewarding when you finally get one. So far Ive found capturing ships to be the funnest and most profitable thing to do. And when you finally get out of the starting gunship into something better it gets a little easier and much more profitable. The learning curve is easy. Not like learning X3 or anything. You can pick it up fairly quick.The game doesnt baby you.. You can run into a battleship that will destroy within minutes of starting the game so you always have to be careful and keep an eye out. There's always a challenge..It's not a game that will allow you to feel like a god that just steam rolls everything that comes along. I like that as it gives you something to strive for. However I will say now that I've gotten a better ship (Its a corvette btw) i come across a lot more ships that are weak or trivial. Its extremely cool when you come into an area with a bunch of them.. I just turn on Auto fire and watch my ship just destroy 5 or 6 ships within minutes.. It's awesome.So far the only things that Ive found to be less than great are the voice acting and traveling..The voice acting is far from good. Its not so bad that it destroys the campaign for you.. But its not good either lol. Your ships computer voice is great though and thats the one you'll hear 90% of the time. The traveling.. When you first start you dont really have a choice but to fly all the way to each location. As warp gates are expensive and not really an option at first. Worm holes do damage and really dont have enough of them to justify them as a good way to travel. Rifts help but they are kind of hard to stay in. So at first the traveling gets kind of old as the map is just so hufmge it can really take a long while to get from one point to another. But after you get a decent income going and you can afford the warp gates its not bad. All in all the game has been an excellent experience. And I feel the user rating should be quite a bit better than it is now. It's a game that I've quickly became addicted to and I already know I'll have hundreds of hours into before I get tired of it.If your looking for a good space rpg, sandbox, freelancer type game this one will not dissappoint.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've logged about 6 hours so far. It's absolutely cut of the same cloth as the freelancer style games. I'm enjoying it, esp. since it scratches an itch I haven't been able to in ages.It runs fine on my aged machine, without ratcheting down the video options. Haven't had any glitches or crashes. It looks pretty, similar to EVE.The UI is taking some getting used to, but I'm pretty competent in a fight now. Only down side there is bounty targets are hard to locate (I've only done so by accident so far.) It's nice that each "role" has some special abilities you can use in combat. Combat flows smoothly. It's neat how you can switch back and forth between direct control and letting your crew fire your guns for you if you need to focus on flying.Oh, yeah: crew. This game isn't single-man fighters like those older games. You CAN stay small, but even then it's a corvette or gunship. But you can also go big, with battleships and carriers. You can hire crew (which grant buffs), and eventually add wingmen to fly a small fleet. I'm looking forward to that.The trading is what you'd expect, and I'm grateful the game tracks high & low prices for you. Currently [in beta] earnings from hunting outstrip trading, so I hope they tweak the economy by launch. You can also mine asteroids and salvage defeated ships.The map starts concealed, and reveals as you explore. This often uncovers missions (bounties, supply or taxi runs, science scans, and rescues so far).Levelling up serves two functions. First you get points to make your special abilities better. Second, for unlocking the better ships. Because it doesn't just give you bigger numbers like a traditional RPG, there isn't a power creep.Over all I'm pretty happy. This is MUCH more playable than the X games.

Early Access Review
								As it stands now, even in Beta, it's a gorgeus game, and you can have great fun with it if you are a fan of the X4 genre or the more arcadish space sims out there. Well worth the money asked for.But I feel it needs a little push in some directions. It can become much more than it is now, if given enough deep and polish. For instance, weapon stats are confusing, and they have no description. Uniqueness and a little story for each weapon/ship/commodity in the world would make it deeper. The huge starmap needs more deepness too, the different factions are not different enough, more involvement in each of them would make it more fun. You need to love some factions and hate others, to be really immersed in the world. Currently, there are only good guys, and bad guys. You shoot the bad guys, that's it :-). Voiceovers and images of the different factions are a must to achieve this.Balance is still a little off, but it's to be expected in beta after all. You can destroy large enemy ships (destroyers or battleships) with your starter ship, without much sweating, but overall it's very fun and asks you for fairly involved gameplay, you need to use special powers and equipment to see it through the large battles unscathed.I know for a fact that the team is constantly updating and expanding the game daily, so I have high hopes for it all to be fullfilled in the end.Must buy for every space combat, space trader lover out there!

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												Dread. Really hate to give this review but here goes.Even the much aligned (by me) Dark Star One is better. It held my attention for 45 hours.7.5 hours into S♥♥♥♥nd I need to give it a thumbs down. I hate to do that given it's an acceptance of money down the drain. You can't win them all.I played Elite on the BBC B computer and all its subsequent upgrades. Long-time player of Eve Online, Freelancer, I War, X Wing and blah blah. Lots of them.Happy to give credit to the developers for trying and improving. I will definitely keep an eye on the new game and hope that is more my cup of tea.The game has a story driven content and a free roaming side. In fact even in the story mode you are quite free to roam around too which is a huge plus. It looks like to me the developers must have tacked the story line late in development as some of the beta testers much have shouted very loud "Ho, hum, what do we do exactly?"Freelancer was the last great Space game and this is not a bad recreation of that. Just that in every aspect it is worse. It has me trying and failing to fit a DVD drive back into my PC so I could install it again.The in-flight movement and combat of your ship is pretty good. There are a few modes and modules to use. There is innovation where you can mostly destroy an opponent and then send some ruffians over to board it. If successful you can tow the ship back to a dock for huge income. Combat is pretty satisfying with options to fire yourself or computer controlled auto-fire. All thumbs up. I am told that as you upgrade your ship the movement in flight will also change. So big cargo ships move slower than smaller fast ships.Your pilot can improve his skills as you level up. This is also innovation for this type of game. To my rookie eye though these skills seem to be mostly +5% this and that. Your on-board computer scans the local area and identifies bounty opportunities and exploration is positively encouraged. The computer even remembers prices of commodities in every place you have docked which makes it very easy to trade away at the beginning. Whether you can do that as a main way of attaining riches I can't say. The prices of ships are very high.The universe itself feels slightly alive as you can pass fellow ships in your travels and scan and attack them for piracy fun. Planets and space stations have some small radio chatter that comes across.So why the thumbs down? Freelancer remains better and that was released years ago. It had better story line, graphics, ships, reputation system. Well, almost everything. I have hope though and if I ever play this one more will update this review. You might like it.

Posted: August 26, 2016
												Dread. Really hate to give this review but here goes.Even the much aligned (by me) Dark Star One is better. It held my attention for 45 hours.7.5 hours into S♥♥♥♥nd I need to give it a thumbs down. I hate to do that given it's an acceptance of money down the drain. You can't win them all.I played Elite on the BBC B computer and all its subsequent upgrades. Long-time player of Eve Online, Freelancer, I War, X Wing and blah blah. Lots of them.Happy to give credit to the developers for trying and improving. I will definitely keep an eye on the new game and hope that is more my cup of tea.The game has a story driven content and a free roaming side. In fact even in the story mode you are quite free to roam around too which is a huge plus. It looks like to me the developers must have tacked the story line late in development as some of the beta testers much have shouted very loud "Ho, hum, what do we do exactly?"Freelancer was the last great Space game and this is not a bad recreation of that. Just that in every aspect it is worse. It has me trying and failing to fit a DVD drive back into my PC so I could install it again.The in-flight movement and combat of your ship is pretty good. There are a few modes and modules to use. There is innovation where you can mostly destroy an opponent and then send some ruffians over to board it. If successful you can tow the ship back to a dock for huge income. Combat is pretty satisfying with options to fire yourself or computer controlled auto-fire. All thumbs up. I am told that as you upgrade your ship the movement in flight will also change. So big cargo ships move slower than smaller fast ships.Your pilot can improve his skills as you level up. This is also innovation for this type of game. To my rookie eye though these skills seem to be mostly +5% this and that. Your on-board computer scans the local area and identifies bounty opportunities and exploration is positively encouraged. The computer even remembers prices of commodities in every place you have docked which makes it very easy to trade away at the beginning. Whether you can do that as a main way of attaining riches I can't say. The prices of ships are very high.The universe itself feels slightly alive as you can pass fellow ships in your travels and scan and attack them for piracy fun. Planets and space stations have some small radio chatter that comes across.So why the thumbs down? Freelancer remains better and that was released years ago. It had better story line, graphics, ships, reputation system. Well, almost everything. I have hope though and if I ever play this one more will update this review. You might like it.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												This is not an easy review to write.. As a veteran, sometimes elitist, critical gamer, I have a lot of reasons to not like this game in it's release condition, and this review is probably going to drag on a while, to TLDR: Yes, it's worth getting, if for no other reason than the potential it has as a modding platform for other game ideas.So, where to start?... Contrary to the normal rant I been seeing in the review of how special it is, I see it as a rather run of the mill space game, not too undifferent from many others I've played over the past few decades. It's an external space shooter with turrets, which leads many people to compare it to Eve, but it is nothing like Eve.Though I have yet to finish it, much resembles the game model set by classics like Elite or Privateer in which you fly around in your ship, in a go wild, lots of things to do and keep you busy, bad guys everywhere type setting with a pretty basic storyline that is format enought (so far) that it coulda been adapted to any setting and is not really science fiction in it's core, but they have set the story in space.It is definitely fictional through and through, as there is almost nothing realistic about anything in the game.. No real physics, a very cluttered space and so much graphics effects crammed into it that it's a wonder you can see through all the fog, debri, warp tunnels, nebula, etc. that are floating around... The game suffers through and through with what the guys at Penny Arcade's Extra Credits would call designing for coolness, not for actual plot value or realistic immersion... It's clearly programed for visual bells and whistles, cramming in things like they had a long list of 'It would be cool if you could have X" type design notes with little thought or reason to how it all fits together or in any way helps the plot... There are junk clouds, asteroid clouds, nebula, Stargates, wormholes, slipstream channels (or green tubes of suckage as many have taken to calling them).. and most of the combat is pretty basic and uninspired... and it's got it's bugs and design issues as well.All that said, why do I still recommend it? Well, for two reasons.1.) It's definitely modable and almost from day 1 various 1st gen mods started rolling out, so the game can be loaded with features and has potential far beyond the state it's in now.2.) The devs seem extremely involved, are active in the community, take bug reports and comlaints seriously and are still very much in the polishing and debugging state of the game with a very fast iteration speed on fixes.Putting all this together, it's an okay game that was designed more for visual coolness than anything serious, but it has potential far beyond what it currently is, and will probably get much better before the Devs are done polishing it.

Posted: April 2, 2016
												Great game, apart from the physics.It's the game Freelancer could have become if Microsoft hadn't killed it. The artwork is impressive, the variety is good, and in general I liked it.The only issue I have with the game, and this is a major issue for me, is the flight physics. It's a SPACE sim. That means that when I turn off my engine, I expect to keep going until I say otherwise. Not here. In this game, they've decided that space is really just air-based fighters where you can't fall down. Turn off the engine? Immediate stop. Try to coast so you can move in one direction but face another? Not possible - you only move forward. Freelancer had this right. These guys? Not at all. I initially recommended the game, but find that I can't honestly do that. If you want a jet fighter game set in space then yes, I'd strongly recommend this game.  If you're expecting a SPACE game look somewhere else, as I'm doing.I'm still searching for a game that was as elegant as Freelancer, with newtonian* physics, simplified flight systems (so Evochron Mercenary, with its ridiculously overcomplicated flight systems and 90's inspired console graphics doesn't really do it for me either), and a decent single-player campaign but sufficiently creative random campaigns to keep things interesting afterwords. Drop me a note if you have any suggestions.======* After reading several reviews, I see that "newtonian" needs to be defined. "Newtonian" physics is simple. It means that if I put my ship in motion on a specific vector, I will remain on that vector unless I do something to change it. Turning off the engines should NOT stop me cold in "space". I should just keep going until I do something to change my vector. That "something" includes turning on docking assist, braking thrusters, or what-have-you. I'll accept "slowing down slowly" (space dust, donchaknow) but not "stops as if stuck in mud". If I wanted to play "cars in thick mud" I'd play a land-based game.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												For the "tl;dr" crowd:  7/10Almost 80 hours in, I found the game to be enjoyable for a space sim.  Many similarities to the "X" franchise (I have over 200 hours in "X2: The Threat"), but somewhat "lighter" in comparison.Game mechanics are adequate (stations, planets, commodities, equipment, etc,), and do not get in the way of game play.  Conversely, they are not "deep" (no stock exchange, no station building/owning, no empire building), so there comes a point where it becomes routine and a bit boring.  I only played a "Gunner", and did not engage in all of the the game's offerings (mining, bounty hunting, etc.).I found leveling to be almost too easy.  I would expect higher levels to become asymptotically harder to achieve, but the experience points required to level seemed to be rather linear.  After 78 hours of simultaneous freelance and story line, I was at level 79 ("Fleet Admiral"), where the story campaign was only requiring level 40.  If you want the story line to remain challenging, you should probably stick to it until it is complete, and then freelance.Graphics are above average.  I always play with everything on high, so the space junk, asteroids, nebulea, visual effects, etc. really added to the immersion.  One of the bright points of the game engine is that nothing in space is instanced.  You fly through space, going from one grid tile to another, without having to transition in any way.  The only transitions in the game happen with the Jump Gates, T-Drive or Wormholes, which one would expect.Combat is enjoyable, with enough going on to keep it interesting.  It doesn't take long, however, to know when enemies will ambush you, what specific loadout will let you take down a Hero, etc.  I rarely died in the game, and when I did, it was typically when there were just too many enemies concentrating their fire on me (and no allies in the vicinity to pull aggro for me), or when I accidently left my "Fire At Will" mode engaged and approached a station with enemies docked.It is a 1.2 release as of this writing, and I have still experienced a few bugs.  The most ubiquitous is a "Maintenence" mission not completing following combat enroute (either by ambush or just encountering enemies along the way).  One that just hit me, that caused me to stop playing, was my entire equipment inventory suddenly disappeared after a T-Drive jump and an ambush when I materialized.  I went to change my equipement loadout (swap the T-Drive with Energy Shield for the fight), and my rather robust equipment inventory was just gone!  I tried several things, but I couldn't get it back, and decided that was enough.I recommend the game to anybody who enjoys this genre (my favorite), and who is looking for a less-stressful diversion from the higher-order space simulations.

content:
Posted: April 23
												Star Point Genimini 2 is an open world space sim with tons of ships to choose from and plenty of space to blow them up in. The combat is fairly basic but in a good fight can become tactical in some manners, such as shield/armor/speed tanking. The weapons are not too exciting, small variety and needs some randomization to help with the very few good weapons in the game (Rail guns are basically the best i have noted, accuracy and dmg).The graphics are pretty and the ships are fun to look at.  Though even on low settings my computer has a lot of lag when traveling from sector to sector (specs below*).  It runs alright on a laptop but still laggy.The map is fairly big with random events that are basically all you do, which in turn makes the story line very bland.  The story line itself is lethargic and not very engaging and the voice acting does not help.  The missions get fairly repetitve, go here blow this up or repair that thing, however, there is a fair variety of ways to make cash.  I thought its cool you can capture enemy ships and sell them. Trading and mining are pretty mediocre, but in a big ship you can haul more. You need a constant income to keep up your fleet, this can be challenging sometimes because you just bought a bunch of shiny stuff, which will just bottom out later in the game because you have the best crap. All in all i recommend this game, its pretty dope and simple to play, it definately needs some balancing and factions dont really matter.  It can be a little CPU heavy at times on a laptop.  Be prepared for a lot of down times, there can be a lot of flying around to do.7.5/10Pros: Fun and Easy GameplayGood Looking Ships And Tons Of ThemChallengingAddictiveGood Diversity Of Money MakingCons:Lame Story Line HUD Needs Some Help (Mostly Needs A Target Disply On The HUD)Controls Can Be A Little WonkyNeeds Balancing (Ships and Weapons / Not Enough Actual Variety)Faction Relations Only Matter If You Are Trying To DockIntel Core i3-6100U 2.3 GHzIntel HD 5204 GB RAM

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												This game is unbalanced. Apart from an unengaging story line with bare-bones, tired story missions, the free roam (the idea of which I love) becomes stalled and unsatisfying because of the unbalanced gameplay. Your rank quickly surpasses your ability to upgrade to better ships. This means the missions generated for your rank level are mostly impossible - as noted by the threat lvl attached to your target's info display IMPOSSIBLE - because you're still flying around in a pea shooter. Impossible engagements for missions of my level? That's absurd! I quickly realized that at around lvl 10, the only time I was actually completing those missions was when heavy allied ships were there to do the brunt of the damage. I realized I was doing next to nothing, very unsatifying, and only survived because the target's fire was directed elsewhere. So you spend your time wandering aimlessly trying to find easier missions which are few and far between. Also maddening is capturing ships - far and away the best means for generating credits - but which is nearly always hampered by allied ships blowing your target away before you can either commence or complete a capture attemptSo, if you like withering fire directed at your ship (who's shields are about as strong as plastic wrap), love constantly wrangling with camera controls, love grinding hour after hour after hour for little gain, and you absolutely adore constantly reloading save games, go get this thing. You'll love it.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												TL; DR Its a trap! Great fun at start, absolutely mind numbingly boring towards the end. You start with a gunship and the map is huge right? Then you fly around doing freelance missions (10k each) to get your first ship which costs around 200k. After a while, you notice the 200k ship is not so different then the one you have, so you start eyeing that 2m ship which is significantly better. But how can you get 2m? By boarding other ships, thats how. The game is as long as it takes you to get that first 2m ship, philedelphia if I remember correctly. After that you resupply your marines and look for other ships. doing it will net you around 30m + some dreads. It took me 3-4 days to get that 2m ship since I enjoyed every view, mission and etc for a while. Everything was challenging. I thought the game was a little like eve. No.Around the 5 day mark I almost had/sold/destroyed every ship in the game and I was invincible. A mission? let me just warp in to melee range and press f (auto fire). A side mission 15 levels above? No problem. Massive battle near station with 10+ enemy ships packed together + hero? Let me just warp in melee again and turn different sides of my ship since shields on one side went down to 50%.  After 5 days of casual play there was NOTHING to contest my ship and I had not even started the MAIN CAMPAIGN. Noticing this, I immediately started the campaign and finished it in several hours. Everyone was saved, lots of joy, yay. But, nothing changed on the map. I had somehow brought the dlc's as well, and there is a bug in titans main quest which forces you to free roam. There are fixes for it but I do not have the patience to "play" this anymore.Oh and you can't destroy enemy stations, hell the shots go right through.Also why are there so few weapons and systems. You buy/capture a 30m ship and all you can put on them are the same measly crap that exists in almost all stations everywhere. There is no chance of variation or strategy. Why the hell would you cloak?

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												It's not a bad game.I wouldn't pay the full price for this game. If you get it on sale, it's definately worth about 40 hrs of your time.--The space combat was very straightforward. Point and shoot. You win, you lose.Exploration was... very simple, almost entirely predictable.There were a lot of asteroid and debri fields. I don't think I spent more than 30min fumbling around in the very first one. I could have missed out on a very important part of the game by ignoring this activity.Trade was well thought out. Unfortunately there was no reason to participate in it. Overwhelming amounts of money had no real purpose. In other games, you could use massive fortunes to create space stations, buy sectors, buy planets, enable trade routes. I never saw that in this game (maybe I just missed it). Capturing and selling ships was more profitable, more entertaining.Money could be used to upgrade a particular weapon, endlessly, but it felt like a lazy money-sink. Investing in it made combat too easy. You could rent wing-men, but they were largely pointless if you acquired the above weapon.An alarming number of ships were useless in almost all situations. There didn't seem to be a way to improve a ship, if you liked it. There were modular upgrades that could be added and removed, but this seemed more like a standard approach - the upgrades must be done or this ship will be even more useless. I mention this, specifically, because I would have traded the money-sink weapon for a money-sink ship improvement system.The acting was good enough. The story was below average (which made the acting seem a lot worse than it was). Playing the main story may actually lower your over-all opinion of this game, which isn't uncommon for a space game. You have the option, in the game, to skip the main story entirely.There were some bugs in the game. Some of the bugs enabled exploits, so I'll avoid detailing them.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Lots of positive reviews on here convinced me to pick this one up while I wait for Star Citizen to drop. The comparisons to EVE are a joke and the two hold nearly nothing in common. Freelancer and Privateer? Sure. More recently, I'd compare this to Galaxy on Fire.SG2 is nothing more than a sandbox space game. If that's all you want then you'll get a decent game. The interface and user experience could use a bit of work as well as additional options to sort/organize commodities and equipment. I honestly didn't expect it to reach version 1 in it's current state and really it could have benefited from several more months of dev time. Customization is very limited. Combat is fairly solid. You're free to do as you please, exploring the galaxy and making friends/enemies wherever you go.I just wish there was something to drive the player beside their own goal. SG2 is lacking any sort of story. No big deal, it's a sandbox; I get it. Little story arc type missions would add so much though. Or a mission board to pick up missions in a more traditional fashion. Or the notion of of carrying out jobs for a particular company as a series of missions and work your way up. As it is, the game consists of flying around without direction, checking your map for freelance opportunities, accepting an opportunity, fly to the waypoint and either kill the badguy, or pick up and deliver cargo.  Mission done. Repeat until you can afford an ungodly expensive new ship and start again. They're the typical space game missions. It's a grind. And for me, if I'm going to grind at least give a me sense of purpose in doing so. Overall, this to me, is still a beta and was rushed out without any clear direction.

This Review is based on the "Freeroam" game and does not concern the storylinesStarpoint Gemini 2 (SP2) is a sort of tactical space-combat simulator with RPG elements. At the start of the game you pick a character avatar and name, a class and one of three starter ships. Then it plops you down in the newbie-friendly area of Planet Trinity and gets you started with some context-sensitive tutorials.Gameplay is fairly straightforward. You have a map of the universe, and as you fly around various missions become available. You can accept any of these missions; they can be a number of things: straight Assassination missions (destroy the target), Escort or protection missions (preserve an allied target and destroy enemy targets), repair missions (fly to a structure and use the middle-click context menu to repair it), taxi missions (fly VIP from point A to point B), smuggle missions (fly contraband cargo from point A to point B). Each mission provides some cash, experience and either positive or negative reputation.The reputation system is not spectacular. There are "bad" factions and "good" factions. Doing missions for the good factions, or blowing up the ships of bad factions, rewards positive rep. Vice-versa for the bad factions. If you want to work with the "bad" factions, you need to acquire negative rep. However, there are a handful of "fanatic" factions that you can never join, and destroying them ALSO rewards positive reputation, even if they are the target of a bad faction mission. I tried a couple playthroughs; the first time I didn't pay any attention to rep and within a few hours I was close to maxing out my positive rep (+2500 points). The next day I attempted to build negative rep, not knowing how the rep system worked (it's not explained well in the tutorials or anywhere else) and it took many hours of trial and error, and reading the Steam discussion forum, to figure out what was going on. In short the game is heavily balanced in favor of working for the "good" factions. The only way to change reputation outside of missions and combat is to find a "good" or "bad" structure and kill it (actually disable it, it's still there in a deactivated state) by holding down the fire button for a solid minute or two.Making cash in the game is equally frustrating. Most missions provide piddly amounts of cash, and the biggest incentive to earn money is to buy a bigger, badder ship. Missions also award experience, however, and raising your level tends to raise the level of threats you face. At level 10 there is a rather steep increase to the difficulty of missions involving combat. You are probably still in your gunship, when your targets become freighters and destroyers. This is even in the easiest area of the map (areas of the map are "leveled" in some aspect; how exactly is somewhat opaque). Effectively this locks you out of the most fun and rewarding missions, those involving combat. Inquiries to the devs on the Steam forums as to how this leveling-scaling works were ineffective.Ironically, the best way to make money is to simply pirate other ships. This is not inherently a "bad" move: as long as you are pirating the ships of the "bad" factions, you will gain positive reputation. Pirated ships call sell for between 100k to a million or more, depending on the ship and it's cargo. Capturing a ship is a fairly simple game of "who has more troopers". Even with extensive buffing of your troopers strength via skills and perks, it's effectively impossible to take a ship that has more men; taking one with equal numbers is a roll of the dice. There are videos available on the interwebs explaining this in more detail. Again, none of this is addressed in-game.There is more to talk about, such as the levelling, the exploration aspect, and the "sideline" missions that advance some sort of story in freeroam (it seems to be a "good" centric story, unfortunately for people hoping to be an enterprising space pirate; it is however completely optional). But I don't want to go on for ages. Is this game worth $42.00 (core game + DLC)? Absolutely not. It's a fairly amateur product that is struggling with balance and weird game-crashing bugs years after it's debut. The dev company is by their own admission very small, and their players seem to know the game better than them; unfortunately the wiki is highly underdeveloped, leaving brand-new players in the dark. This game was bought while it was on sale at 80% off; $10 is a perfectly reasonable price for a game that will entertain for about a week. If you're interested in deep simulation and RP opportunities, look elsewhere. If you want a pretty simple, fun game that looks good and doesn't take a lot of research to grasp, this may be the title for you.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Thousands of backers and fans who were eager for this game to come out; several years of development to get it just so; and even early-access availability, supposedly to alpha and beta-test the game before its official release.  Yet still, the game is awful.I have only played a few hours of it, but I've managed to compile a small list of incredibly important things that you should know before deciding to purchase this game, in the order of importance:1.  Making in-game currency is slow, almost tedious about 90% of the time.  Granted, you can choose a number of ways in which to generate the income dependent on how you would like to play the game (mining, trading, bounty-hunting, completing freelance missions, etc), but ultimately the amount of money that you generate over time is a very slow crawl and makes purchasing better ships, weapon systems, and other important ship equipment almost not even worth the grind.2.  Because of the fact that you have to grind in order to make any money, you level up faster than you can improve on your equipment.  Upon checking the official forums, I discovered that this is apparently a known issue that they haven't had the chance to fix yet, so it might be patched up at a later time.  As a result of your leveling which outpaces your ship class and ship's equipment, you will continue to face increasing numbers, frequencies, and difficulties of enemies that you will have more and more trouble dealing with until you can finally purchase better equipment.  Of course, this basically means that you're almost always behind the curve no matter what as there is no way to slow down your leveling and everything gives you experience.3.  The statistics which indicate to you how difficult a challenge something is in the game are arbitrary.  For instance, the game will tell you the general threat level of red-outlined ships which are about to attack you, which should be an indication of whether you should stand your ground or turn and flee.  This ranges from "Trivial" to "Impossible."  I have been able to easily beat "Impossible" targets with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ships and almost be totally destroyed by a "Trivial" ship in my brand new cruiser.  This same arbitrary system can be found in the instance of determining whether or not an enemy ship can be boarded and taken over by your troopers.  Generally, the lower the number of troopers on the enemy ship, the easier it'll be to overwhelm them.  This stops being the case after a few levels and, even with the maxed-out perk which increases your troopers' effectiveness by 15%, the smaller number of enemy troopers will steam-roll yours every time.Anyway, that's my two-cents.  On the plus side, the game is pretty and I liked where the setting was headed, but ultimately this is just a ♥♥♥♥♥ier version of EvE Online and not necessarily worth the price.

The developers of this game should be ashamed of the final product they made, especially if you want to charge people what you're asking. My life would have been better served buying burritos and making use of my life time supply of Chipotlaway.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Frankly the worst game I've played in a LONG time.The flight controls want to be simple, but they completely destroy physics to make it possible.  When you throttle down from full speed, you stop on a dime, and when you turn the front of your ship, all of your momentum magically matches the new direction you're pointing.  The old game "Darkstar One" has a similar "fly-by-mouse" control scheme, but has at least SOME concept of physics.Combat in this one is pointless: 50% of the time, the enemies are blown up by mysteriously appearing "friends" before you can even fire a shot, 40% of the time they can be killed with "stop next to them and blow them up with your laser/railgun/whatever" tactics, and 10% of the time you get jumped by a ship so much more powerful than you that it cannot be killed or run away from.If you get tired of the pointless combat, there's a pointless trade economy (any station seems to buy anything you happen to be carrying, so all you do to ensure massive profit is buy anything that's green on the merchant's side, and sell anything that's green on your side).Most of all, there's the insanely boring flying between points...  Space is pretty big, and there's only a minimal form of go-fast mode (not time accelleration, but "Power to Engines"), but that only speeds things up by maybe 2-5x, so that most of the time between pointless combat and pointless trading is spent in boring autopilot, flying between waypoints and watching fake looking asteroids and plasma outside your windscreen.  And if you happen to run into an actual asteroid... no big deal, you bounce off.  Literally 2-7 minutes of uneventful flight between each encounter.  As a side note, the campaign voice acting (including the player) is some of the worst I've heard in years.  Accents change randomly mid-sentence, and the pacing and stresses are often strange.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												After playing through the first few missions you'd be forgiven for thinking this was a pre-release indi title, with awful voice acting of poorly written dialogue giving it a horribly unpolished feel, and a tutorial given in the form of a series of short descriptions you need to click through for each UI element but lacking in any practical examples of how they're used leaving you bewildered as to how you're meant to control your ship.I got my first achievement purely by accident just by following the first waypoint . . . which turned out to be in the core of the planet I was trying to land on rather than, as I'd assumed, at some kind of space elevator docking station.  When I finally figured out how to land, visually it was much the same as crashing into it - I still flew to about the same range but instead of warning me to stop and then exploding, the ship stopped and I got the planet menu.While the game claims to support joystick control it's very much designed for mouse and keyboard, with the mouse leaving the targeting reticle wherever you last clicked something.  I ended up awkwardly using the joystick in my left hand and trying to target with the mouse before giving up in disgust and returning the controls to their default joystickless configuration.The starting spaceship flies like it's on rails regardless of the control method you choose and looking through the keybindings gives me no hope of more maneuverable craft later on - you can move forward, turn and roll.  No backward or lateral movement.  Your best bet in a firefight seems to be to leave the turrets on autofire and do your best to fly out of the way of your target's firing lanes.  High speed dodging just doesn't seem to be in the cards, contrary to what was shown in the trailer.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												I didn't enjoy the game. I played it till I got the controls down. But between a tutorial that dumps a bunch of dialog boxes on me. To a rather clunky space game control setting, I couldn't get myself enwraptured as much as I wanted to. I wanted something that would send me back to the days of Freelancer.For those of you who like space games, it has some real meat, but it is a different veriety of meat, much like the difference between Beef and Chicken.There was a lot of flying around doing nothing, the system travel gates required money and just dropped you into loading screens. And while the scale of the star system is right and the customizability is there. It lacked a certain charm. A polish.Plus!-Customizable Ships-Huge in depth system-Lots of ways to burn timeMinus!-Boring Non-Customizable Campaign Protagonist (I wonder why the same guy gets used game to game, is it the same guy?!)-Clunky combat controls-Flat uninvolving ports and planets. (At least early game)-The Tutorial---Notes to the Devs.I honestly respect the work you put on this game, and I can give you a few pointers.On a thread I read you spoke about how your hands on tutorial didn't please, and how other people complained about this tutorial. There is a middle ground, hear me out.Rather than dump it all at once in a click through while the game is paused, simply in the opening acts give a small, non intrusive note that tells you how to do something, without pausing, or forcing you to do it.For example when you start get a quick side note saying how to fly the ship. When you encounter your first enemy get a little side note without pause saying the right mouse button fires.What you have currently is page after page of tutorial sheets, which, while not as long as EVE is thrown far more upfront. Sure EVE had a lot more tutorial text, but EVE didn't dump it on you the first ten seconds.Secondly, the Protagonist. For a space RPG many people regard who's in the Cockpit as optional or make a character. In this case we have the typical inexperianced yet cocky caucasian male. But my question is, what if you made the protagonist for the actual game slightly more customizable. Give him titles instead of a direct name. Like his father saying 'son' while others call him by other things. Next, why not increase a few lines of dialog by adding gender options, a female voice actor and the ability to choose as many options as Freeroam? Really honestly give the illusion of choice to the player by letting them make the person they play as. Kind of like Bioware did with Shepard, Hawke or the Inquisitor. Sure you don't have to be that in depth about it with 3d renders. But a few portraits and the options would have been amazing.On combat, a good thing that most space games do, is have a lead indicator and a smoother method of control. In this case I felt like I was trying to reign in a finicky second hand robot. And the lack of a lead indicator made dogfighting a pain. (Not impossible, but annoying. I still won, but it wasn't as pleasent.)I think there really isn't much that can be done about the planets, except maybe adding a more visual docking procedure such as an orbital station or docking ring, or some sort of 'Decending/Ascending' animation. Secondly on the Travel Lines, instead of making it a loading screen jump pointer, make it a long thread that you can ride that steadily consumes money as you travel it, and you'll be booted from the stream when you run out or hit abort. Maybe add lane contols and make it work like a highway.---All and All I think this game does a lot right and a lot wrong, and I love the passion I see from the developers and can't wait to hear what Starpoint 3 might hold on the someday. If you come into this expecting the next Freelancer, you're probably not going to enjoy it. And the asking price for the features which are missing are pretty major.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Starpoint Gemini 2 is a game that I really want to like. The combat is fun, the graphics are good, and the open world is pretty...err... pretty, even though it is incredibly static with things like planetary rotation and many animations left completely out.Despite my attempts to like the game, there was one thing that haunted me as I played this game. I could not stop asking myself "why?"Why did I want to tumble through space doing bounties and moving cargo? The story is flat out bland and totally uninteresting, with a typical "avenge my father who the baddies killed" revenge plot (and one of the most rigid and uninspiring protagonists I have ever seen in any game, and the supporting characters are worse by several great orders of magnitude), and the lack of true player enterprise in the sandbox give you no reason to want to progress in this game. Sure, you buy bigger ships and do bigger missions, but what then? Can I take political control of systems and build my own faction? No. Can I buy property and create a business empire and compete with other traders or corporations? No. All the player can really do is just fly missions and shoot stuff, and then get bigger ships to fly bigger missions and shoot bigger stuff.The developers are great, and really work hard (and continue to do so), and I really wish I could give this a positive review, but the fact of the matter is the game is just "meh" on most accounts. Without anything to really motivate me all I could do was let my mind drift to the impression that I was just in a giant empty MMO were I had to play by the AI factions' rules. But I saw no good reason for it to be that way with no player interaction of any sort.So I don't think its an entirely bad game, but as I have no desire to go play it anymore until there is something to motivate me to progress in the game, I don't feel I would be totally honest in recommending it.

												I am so disapointed in this game, despite having "Very positive" steam reviews and 8.1 on metacritic it is abysmal...The controls are awkward, the UI buggy, post processing forcibly disabled on launch? The mouse is sampled based on primary monitor (so moving this game onto second screen is a flat out no no), infact even trying to play windowed is flawed as if you have the game fit to screen + start menu then to select the bottom of the game's UI you have to move the mouse onto the start menu - click and you lose focus on the game.The gameplay is dull (okay it's a space sim but this doesn't come close to games like eve) customisation is petty, the minimum they could put in to claim the functionality is there, and the game is designed with the grind of an MMO. RPG aspects sounds cool, but after playing for 3 hours I was level 10 with one perk, and a whole lot of money not in my account to upgrade my ship passed one new gun.Frankly, if it were possible, I'd get the game refunded. NOT ready for release, NOT funtcional, NOT fun.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game, but I just can't.Let me start with some of the positives:- Great graphics- Ship models look cool- Ton of Factions- Free mode (option to just be a pilot and no story driven action)Cons:- Voice acting and character portriats are horrible. Like listening to a C grade movie actor and the pictures used to display pilots don't make any sense unless everyone is a retro cyber hippie or biker dude.- Horrible tutorial.. literally had no clue where the button was for help until I found it on accident.- Doesn't state why any of the factions like your or hate you. Do I just kill random people to make the enemy like me or what?- Trying to complete a side quest and ships with impossible to kill statues keeps showing up and killing me.. like a lot.. and even when I try to escape, they scramble my engines and kill me.- Stuck with a crappy ship for a long... long... time. Would have been cool to capture a ship a tad bit better than the one your piloting without having to pay Millions of dollars for a so so upgrade. But, the enemy ships that are better have a ton more troops than you do so troops are only usefull to make some quick cash for selling smaller ships.- Being a trader and selling high and buying low would be cool you could carry more than 40 items and the next upgrade that cost me a few million only had 30 slots.. so yea, being a trader would be a horrible way to make money.- Biggest complaint is when you target the enemy by clicking them, then you need to click them with the middle mouse button to pop up the action screen for things like grappling beam, boarding parties, target system or heavy weapon.. THEN the ship flies past you and your menu goes away since the menu is on the ship.. so I have to dog fight and swirl and slow down then speed up just to CLICK them again! Why not have a small display pop up on the side of the screen like EVE so I can base my menu skills off that than trying to follow the ship all over the place while trying to make a decision.Game has some good ideas, but to many cons that just make the game a burden rather than enjoyment. I will only play this game now to beat it just so I don't feel like I wasted my money for nothing.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Lacks polish.UI makes the user think. If the user isn't careful, he/shemay accidently waste credits, as default buy quantity is, for no real good reason, set higher than 1.User may 'magically' gain/lose credits from a transaction that doesn't seem like it should cost anything.That is to say, no cost is advertised in the UI. You find out after you click.In general, unintuitive and poorly designed UI. As is, would have been simpler to have two UI's: one for buying/selling,another for equipping/unequipping. For example, I have no idea what I currently have. Maybe there IS an inventory screen. Do I know about it after spending 3 hours playing? No, so even if there is, the game does not communicate this.All in all, a decent Freelancer like experience, but the UI needs to be redone to be more user friendly and dead simple.
